campaign.story:
Welcome friends, fiends, earthlings, aliens and everyone in between! Introducing: Fates End 2: Terra & Cosmos! 3D printable Dice Towers + MORE for tabletop gaming!   
What you get for Loot-All+ Pledges:    
 The 15 core STL files will be released by August 2021 with all stretch goals being delivered afterwards. All files will be split for smaller printers and are support-free for easy 3D printing! Please Check the PRODUCTION SCHEDULE for release dates! 
_______________________________________________________________
Upcoming Stretch Goals
 *Any unlocked Stretch Goals will be included the my NEXT campaign! 

The Special Social Media Stretch Goal has been UNLOCKED! Say hello to The Heaven & Hell Dice Tower!     
_______________________________________________________________
Add-Ons:
Please see Update #11 for details on how to add Add-ons to your pledge. If you're a new backer, you'll find the option to add Add-ons after you select your pledge level!

Holiday Ornaments! These are really simple but they were a lot of fun to give away to my friends and neighbors last season! I printed mine in resin, about 2" tall and spray painted them with gold or silver spray paint! It's hard to get a photo that does them justice!
BANKS! I gave a way a few bonus banks in the previous campaign (just for fun) but I didn't have the time to get them as perfect as I wanted. Adding this as an Add-on will allow me to use part of my production schedule to develop an improved plug! Here's an example of the Tiamat Bank:
PLAY

_______________________________________________________________
FatesEnd has partnered with Mythos Games for a very special Stretch Goal Bonus! For every $10k raised in this campaign, we will donate one table top game to our local Children's Hospital! Thanks Mythos Games!  
_______________________________________________________________
Do you want to print test a file first? 
That's cool, we get that, so we're giving away one Dice Tower for free. Click below to get a FREE Mayan Temple Dice Tower .STL file to print today!    
_______________________________________________________________
--------------> ALL files are Print Tested and Repaired before release! <---------------
_______________________________________________________________
Concept art of all Core Set items:
5 Sci-Fi-Inspired Dice Towers
5 Earth-Inspired Dice Towers
4 Dice Jails/vaults
& 1 GM Screen     
_______________________________________________________________
More Details
Why Dice Towers? Dice towers help to prevent cheating - and allow Fate do her job! Dice Towers also add an extra level of character to your game! Each tower will include a dice tray to help protect fancy pants tables from heavy metal dice damage. Lastly (our favorite) these Dice Towers inspire envy in friend and foe alike! Enjoy that clackity-clack until fate has rendered her verdict.       
PLAY

_______________________________________________________________
What's a Dice Jail/Vault? Ah, good question! We didn't know either when we launched our previous campaign  but due to UNPRECEDENTED feedback (begging and pleading) from backers, we offered Dice Jails as stretch goals. Since then, the feedback (begging and pleading) has continued, so we were sure to provide LOTS of Dice Jails and Dice Vaults in this campaign. So, what are they? Dice Jails are intended to punish bad dice in style. Dice Vaults are for less naughty dice who need a place to stay for the night... or until their next adventure commences. 
_______________________________________________________________
EASY TO PRINT! The files will be designed to be 3D Printed easily without supports! (Supports are the WORST!)   
Actual FDM print (60% at .15 mm layer height)
_______________________________________________________________ 
Do you actually print your files? Yep, I do, then I print it again, and sometimes... again. 
PLAY

_______________________________________________________________
All files will be designed to print on smaller FDM Printers like the Prusa Mini. Files above 7" (about 177mm) tall will be split into two models so they’re printable on smaller printers. 
_______________________________________________________________
Can I print it even smaller? These objects can be any size that your printer can support, so you can print them smaller (if you have a small printer) or larger (for large dice) if desired.  All Dice towers are designed to work with standard 20mm dice at 100% scale. (*Dice set/tower scales are determined by the size of the D20 in the set.) If you can't print the towers at 100%, then print them at 60% to work with tiny 12mm dice sets (can be found in local game stores or on Amazon.) Teeeny tiny printers such as the Photon and Mars are unlikely to print the majority of dice towers AND work with existing dice. However, Dice Jails and Vaults may work, depending on size and scale. 
 (Photo of actual printed objects ^) 
Actual Resin print
_______________________________________________________________
Have bigger dice? No problem! You can 3D print these files at any scale (*that your printer can support!). Use the dice scaler tab in the PRODUCTION SCHEDULE to determine scale. 
_______________________________________________________________
What printers are supported? All files will be designed to fit within 7" square print areas (Prusa Mini). Files will be split vertically to fit taller printers.      
Printed in Resin (60%)
_______________________________________________________________
I don't have a 3D printer, how do I get a physical product? Although we won’t be selling physical prints through this campaign, we will be offering a Merchant tier that allows the sale of physical prints of all 15 core products, plus ALL unlocked stretch goals. We had a plethora of Merchants with our previous campaign, and we expect (hope) we can duplicate the same success here! 
_______________________________________________________________
Will you be including 6 tray types for towers in this campaign? Sadly, no. Instead of offering 6 simple trays, we wanted to focus on unique designs for each tray for this campaign.  All tower files will come with one removable tray. Our hope is to include spaces to hold dice, but all trays may not have a great spot for dice. Trays will be only one size, one type. In collecting feedback from the previous campaign, we found that the majority of backers were printing the same trays (large.) If we get enough feedback, we may consider an additional tray type (OpenLock perhaps?) but at this moment, one tray is what is being offered in this campaign.
Trays that are too large for our 7"x7"x7" print minimum will be split into parts using puzzle shapes for easy assembly. 
_______________________________________________________________
Can you teach me how to 3D Print? We have a Fates End Print Support Group on Facebook for all backers with lots of volunteers who can help you get started. Many of our backers from the previous campaign were first time printers, and were able to get up and running with the help of our volunteers. 
We will send the Facebook Link out to all backers after the campaign funds (usually two weeks after the campaign ends.)
_______________________________________________________________
 When will I get the files? 
Each object will take about 1 week to model, print test, repair and deliver. GM screen(s) will take two weeks. Please check the PRODUCTION SCHEDULE for Release dates.
Those who back the FatesEnd #1 & #2 or Dual License tiers will receive their FatesEnd #1 files after this campaign funds (*usually two weeks after the campaign ends.)
_______________________________________________________________ 

Quotes from backers of FatesEnd 1 (previous campaign):     
_______________________________________________________________
Previous Campaign (FatesEnd 1)
If you're interested in adding files from the previous FatesEnd campaign (FatesEnd1), but you'd like to see them first, you can find renders, photos and details here. 
PLAY

_______________________________________________________________
Improvements
We'll be fulfilling orders from this campaign through Backerkit! We're hoping for a better/clearer process for file access this time around. 

Since this is our 2nd campaign, we learned a lot from the previous one. We believe this experience will help us communicate more effectively to help fulfillment run smoothly! 
_______________________________________________________________
 MERCHANTS 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>IMPORTANT NOTICE<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
New Merchants: The Merchant license from this campaign does not apply to the previous campaign (FatesEnd1) If you want to sell FatesEnd1 assets, we offer the Dual License for new Merchants.
Merchants from FatesEnd1: you do not need to purchase a Dual License since you already have a license to sell assets from FatesEnd1 (The first campaign). However, if you wish to sell assets from this campaign (FatesEnd2), you must back the Merchant License tier.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>><<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
Our Merchant program in our previous campaign was a huge success! Many Merchants sold so many towers/dice jails from the previous campaign, they were able to expand their print space into a full fledged printer farm! Some Merchants were even able to convert their printing hobby into a full time job from selling FatesEnd merch! To be clear, we can't guarantee the success of every Merchant (that's honestly up to you), but it was fun to see the success of many of our Merchants, especially those who were actively engaged on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, etc.
IMPORTANT NOTE: No one is permitted to sell prints form this campaign (FatesEnd2) unless they back the Merchant License tier, or the Dual License Tier from this campaign. Selling/giving away files is strictly prohibited. 
______________________________________________________________
License duration: The license is good for a full 24 months from the date of the last released file. The more stretch goals we unlock, the longer you can sell! 
______________________________________________________________
Merchant ID. To protect our Merchants and their investment, every Merchant receives a unique Merchant ID. This makes it easy to spot sellers who haven't acquired a Merchant License and put a stop to their piracy (Yarrrrr! Avast ye swabs!)

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my second campaign. The first one blasted past all of my expectations. I've learned a lot from the process, and although we had a few hiccups in the beginning, I believe, in the end, that it was a successful campaign. We have an active community of backers who support one another, and to me, that's the biggest success I could have hoped for.

I feel that there is very little risk this time around. I own all the software, hardware and a lot of learnings from the previous campaign. 

Challenge 1: Manufacturing/modeling easy to print items
Solution - Experience! I’ve been 3D Printing since 2015 and modeling since 2013. In that time, I’ve learned how to create models that don’t require supports, rafts or high infill. (Honestly, complex creations that require supports are the BANE of 3D printing! Many swarings have happened in this house due to the struggles of printing items that require complex supports.) I have owned 11+ printers (no kidding!) We currently have 3 Prusa MK3’s, 3 Prusa Minis, an Elegoo Saturn and a Anycubic Mono X.

Challenge 2: Time
Solution - Self-employed! I have the time planned out to create the remaining files for this campaign. I have the software, hardware, skill and experience, all I need is time. I am self-employed so I have complete control over my time! All I have to do is schedule the time in, and boom - we’re on track!
By funding this project, you make it possible for me to focus on this project instead of client work for a time. YOU are my client! Let’s make this happen, together!

campaign.story:
Two projects in one! This Kickstarter campaign offers two dramatically different works:
 Illuminated Manuscript. A collection of web, unpublished, and older articles pulled from the company's history. Starting at 24 pages, the zine expands in size as stretch goals are unlocked and we add more articles to the collection!
 1976 Ogre Playtest Booklet. Constructed from scans of Steve's typewritten and hand-illustrated Ogre playtest set, this saddle-stitched booklet gives you a look at Ogre in its pre-publication form. Have you always wanted to learn more about Steve's first game? This book pulls back the curtains and gives you a version of the game you've not seen before!
Read on to learn more about both zines!
At project launch, Illuminated Manuscript includes a mix of web articles, the winning entry in our recent Ogre playmat scenario contest, and material from the pages of Where We're Going -- our retailer newsletter -- from 1987 and 1988.  
Digital mockup. This article showcases the progress of GURPS Space in 1987/1988, as documented in the pages of the Where We're Going Newsletter. This hard-to-find newsletter for retailers and distributors includes info that wasn't shared with GURPS players at the time the book was being created. Final may vary slightly in appearance.
Project stretch goals, if unlocked, add another twelve pages to the zine, expanding the total size to 36 pages. (See stretch goals, below, for more information.) These stretch goals include more web content and previously unreleased material. 
 The articles at project launch include:
Deluxe Illuminati: The Servants of Cthulhu Solitaire Challenge
GURPS Space, The Albatross of 1987/1988*
 Halloween d6 Dice Set Rules by Steve Jackson 
Eyes on the Prize, An Ogre Scenario**
 It’s Munchkin Party Time! with Andrew Hackard 
Designer’s Notes: Cthulhu Dice
Thinking Outside of the Box**
 Army Men d6 Dice Set Rules 
Munchkin Dungeon Design: For Munchkins, By Munchkins
 * From Where We're Going and Roleplayer (1987/1988)
** New to Illuminated Manuscript.
"This is a reproduction of an actual surviving Ogre playtest set from 1976. It consists of the rules (typed on typewriter – no word processors yet!), the map (hand-drawn by me, with the sophisticated graphics talent for which I am NOT famous), and the game counters (also hand-made by me)." 
- Steve Jackson, from the introduction (written in 2021)

Digital mockup of the 1976 Ogre Playtest Booklet. Final may vary slightly in appearance.


What an incredible treat! Dated November 4, 1976, this is Steve's typewritten playtest set for the original Ogre game. We've scanned the pages and have presented them exactly as the marked copies appear. Have you wanted a look at Ogre in its pre-publication form? This is your chance to add an unusual collectible to your Ogre library!
The booklet comes in at 20 pages (which includes the cover, back cover, and inside covers). The center includes the map. We will release the PDF as a free title once this Kickstarter campaign has closed, so you won't have to cut your booklet if you want to build the set and play the game as it existed in 1976.
Digital mockup of the 1976 Ogre Playtest Booklet. Final may vary slightly in appearance.
NOTE: None of the project stretch goals impact the content of the 1976 Ogre Playtest Booklet. This saddle-stitched zine is 100% maxed out in terms of page count and ready to go at project launch. One stretch goal upgrades the physical construction of the booklet. See below.
If unlocked, these stretch goals directly impact the Illuminated Manuscript zine.
 $2,000 - UNLOCKED! - +4 pages added to the Illuminated Manuscript. (Ogre Sixth Edition vs Designer's Editon comparison and Cthulhu Dice spell effects for fantasy RPGs*) 
 $3,500 - UNLOCKED! - +4 pages added to the Illuminated Manuscript. (Spiral Summoning for The Fantasy Trip* and Zombie Dice Designer's Notes) 
 $5,000 - UNLOCKED! - +4 pages added to the Illuminated Manuscript. (Munchkins & Mazes Designer's Notes, Gelatinous Solitaire Rules, and One On One Munchkin Monster Melee*) 
* New to Illuminated Manuscript.
If this stretch goal is unlocked, we will add three copies of a new Munchkin bookmark to all print reward levels. (This bookmark will be released as a free promo later in 2021.)
 $7,500 - UNLOCKED! - Munchkin Bosses bookmark. What is Munchkin Bosses? A new mini-expansion scheduled for release later in 2021! NEW! 
If this stretch goal is unlocked, we improve the physical construction of the 1976 Ogre Playtest Booklet.
 $10,000 - UNLOCKED! - The cover of the 1976 Ogre Playtest Booklet is upgraded to a heavier stock. 
If unlocked, the next stretch goal adds another four pages to the Illuminated Manuscript zine!
 $13,000 - UNLOCKED! - +4 pages added to the Illuminated Manuscript. (Confessions of a Tree-Hugger, How it Got to be Z-Shot, and Dragons*. All by Steve Jackson! Dragons is an unpublished dice game using standard six-sided dice.) 
* New to Illuminated Manuscript.
If the next stretch goal is unlocked, all reward levels receive one copy each of the two coaster designs. These are the same size/style as the coasters currently available at Warehouse 23. 
 $15,000 - UNLOCKED! - Two different coasters, one Ogre and one The Fantasy Trip, added to each reward level.
All stretch goals unlocked!

The Illuminated Manuscript and 1976 Ogre Playtest Booklet rewards levels are unlimited; we will print as many zines as necessary to meet demand. Other reward levels may include limits. If those limits are met, we will review the situation and open up more slots when possible.


 NOTE: Street addresses only.
After the Kickstarter project closes, and after all pledges are collected, we will open the BackerKit pledge manager. There, you will tell us your Warehouse 23 email address, provide your physical address, and pay for shipping. You will also have the chance to add more items to your rewards package. Failure to complete your BackerKit survey by the deadline (which will be announced in a Kickstarter update once the pledge manager opens) will result in a refund and removal from the project. If you wish, you may choose to use a fulfillment service. This allows you to pledge for the project and then provide us with a U.S. address for the delivery of your rewards. Forwarding from the fulfillment service, as well as any local fees, is your responsibility when using a fulfillment company.

campaign.story:
I couldn't stay away.
ZineQuest is a really cool initiative, and I've never participated.
So, I made a zine. Not fancy. It's all very DIY and all the work is done by me. I've been noodling on hacking up a d100 OGL system for a while, and I'd been tinkering with the ruleset during down hours. So I sat down and finished it, did some layout stuff on it, and built this Kickstarter page, all in six hours. 
Short of drawing all the art myself, it doesn't get more DIY than that. (I debated drawing the art myself, but I figured I'd spare you.)
So. Swordpoint is a d100 swashbuckling-themed zine using the Legend OGL (from Mongoose Publishing). The tone and theme is inspired by Musketeers, Captain Alatriste, and European Continent around the 1600s, as well as older games like En Garde, Flashing Blades, and more.
The rules are condensed to about 60 pages in a 5"x8" landscape format. I always wanted to try a landscape book, and I like how they read on tablets and phones, so I figured why not.
I did all the layout myself, so it's not super fancy, but I tried to keep it simple and functional. 
What it has:
The rules you need to play. A hacked d100 system (it'll feel familiar if you know d100 RPGs.)
New rules for this iteration of the d100 RPG: Style points. Streamlined combat. A lightweight magic system. 
Genre rules for grudges, revenge, rank, duels, and some enemies (not many enemies though. Like 3.)
A planned compatibility license.
 PDF bookmarks. I just learned how to do that this morning!
Character sheet mock-up I made. We'll see.
What it doesn't have:
Lots of rules.
Lots of art. Most of the art is from Shutterstock or public domain. There's only like 5-6 pieces in the book total, just to fill white space.
Fancy layout. Remember: DIY and I am not a layout artist. It should be pretty straightforward and easy to read though.
Stretch goals (at least right now.)
The writing is probably kinda dry. I wrote in very technical style, 'cause I was inspired by older RPGs (one of my proof-readers even commented on that, so I figure I'll warn you.)
Layout Sample

The Plan
Once we close, I'll send the PDF out to backers to submit feedback. I think we got most of the errors, but I've learned not to count on that. I'll incorporate the feedback. Then we'll go to print and delivery. No muss, no fuss. 
Shipping
Physical is shipping to the US only. Sorry. It sucks and I hate having to restrict it but it's too easy to lose money or get caught unawares by shipping changes (hey Brexit.) 
Extra will be available via the GKG webstore after the campaign though, so if you want, you can get it then and we'll try to give you the best rate possible. 
GKG has shipped thousands of packages, so it should be pretty straightforward.

The system is pretty simple! Each month, you choose a theme and we create assets that are matching that theme for the Townbuilder, as well as a number of print-ready buildings that you can download immediately.
If you back this Kickstarter you will receive a code that will, once redeemed, automatically unlock the release for the current month and all following months for the duration you backed for.
If you are supporting any miniature sculptors on Patreon, you will already have an idea how such a system plays out. The only difference is, that you will get buildings and customization assets instead of miniatures, and they will be available on townsmith.de instead of google drive/MyAirBridge/Sync.
Access to the Townbuilder Software is not included in the subscription, but also not necessarily needed. Please read the section "TB not included" for more information.

Basically, each release is a number of models (Walls, Floors, Doors, Windows, Roofs, etc...) that are fitting the theme of that month and are automatically unlocked for your account as soon as they are available.
Additionally, we will create a number of print-ready, support-free buildings, that you can download as a zip file that includes everything you need. You can also customize the buildings with any models of prior releases or our last Kickstarter in the Townbuilder.
There are a total of 6 releases planned in this Kickstarter, with more to come if the system is profitable. Depending on your pledge you receive a total of 3 or 6 such releases!

Subscribing after these initial 6 months is optional and you will be asked if you want to stay subscribed when you enter your activation codes.
We would love for you to stay subscribed and allow us to expand the Townbuilder each month for a long time, but you can also use this Kickstarter without binding yourself to a subscription and just get the 6 months of assets and buildings.

Now let's talk about our last Kickstarter, Townbuilder Unlimited, which was really successful and allowed us to make the Townbuilder much bigger than we ever anticipated! But as many of you know, that Kickstarter has not yet been completely fulfilled. But as you can see in the delivery dates, there is plenty of time for us to finish the last stretch goals before the first monthly release is due.

I assume that most people who stumble across this Kickstarter are either backers of our last campaign or bought the Townbuilder shortly after on MMF, BackerKit or in our store.
But for those of you who are new to Townsmith, here is a quick overview:
PLAY

We really can't explain what the Townbuilder is any better than our info page can: Townbuilder Info Page
TLDR: The Townbuilder is a web-based custom creator for 3D-printable buildings for tabletop games. You can combine small building blocks, such as walls, floors, roofs, and stairs, into complete buildings.
Ah, and of course, if you don't own the Townbuilder yet, you should head over to our store and have a look at it! There are already plenty of models that you can use to create buildings.
If you decide to get the Townbuilder, I HIGHLY recommend watching our User Guide Youtube Playlist, it helps a lot with getting started!


About a year and a half has passed since Tom and I had the idea for the Townbuilder. Initially, it started as a side project next to our university studies.
Well, we're certainly not at that point anymore. We had a very successful Kickstarter last year and since then the Townbuilder has gone from Open Beta to Early Access 0.1-0.4 and finally to Townbuilder v1.0.
But what exactly has improved and changed in the software since you last saw it on Kickstarter?
Improved Performance
Increased Server capacities by a factor of 10
Implemented under the hood services that allow us to better monitor the performance and problems of the Townbuilder
Implemented OpenLOCK capabilities
Developed our own peg and magnet system, allowing for 1-6mm magnets and pegs to be placed on almost any model
Created a peg placement mode that makes it much more convenient to place pegs
Enabled scaling of the exported building to a variety of popular scales
Started a partner system to get models of other designers into the Townbuilder
Added Fillerblocks, a way to fill out empty space or use them as placeholders (cube, cylinder, prism, floor-like)
Added a grouping system that gives the user full control over which models are exported as one STL
Added a group linking system that expands the grouping functionality to allow for multiple floors to be linked together for export
Added Building Blocks, a way of saving and importing whole buildings into your workspace, enabling creative users to fully modularize their building process
Added animations to different elements
Reworked the entire GUI making it responsive on smaller and larger monitors.
Created the Signbuilder, a sub-application for the Townbuilder, with which you can create signs with custom text and logos that can be used in the Townbuilder
Fixed 500+ bugs
Had the servers burn down 3 times
WIP on (semi-)automatic mesh repair using Netfabb so models can be used in all slicers (Simplify3D users rejoice!)
WIP on a link sharing system, that allows users to share their builds via unique URLs
WIP on creative mode that allows users to build with all existing assets, save and share the building, but not export it as an STL
WIP on on-click merchant integration that will allow users to send out print-commission request to our licensed merchants directly from the Townbuilder

We will also post this in the FAQ, but just to be clear:
Does the subscription include access to the software?
NO, IT DOESN'T. THIS KICKSTARTER IS JUST ABOUT A MONTHLY EXPANSION OF MODELS AND PRINT-READY BUILDINGS!

If you backed our last Kickstarter, you already got a lifetime license to the Townbuilder.
This system will not change and will remain as it is for the foreseeable future. We do not charge you extra, nor do we give new people cheaper options to get the Townbuilder.

You can back this Kickstarter without owning the Townbuilder and you will still get all the STLs for the buildings. However, you will not be able to customize them unless you backed our last Kickstarter or you specifically backed one of the following reward tiers:
Townbuilder Advanced + 6 Months Subscription
Townbuilder Pro + 6 Months Subscription
Townbuilder All In

With this Kickstarter, our stretch goals will depend on the number of backers, NOT on the money raised. That is because this number gives us a rough estimate of how many subscribers we will have in any given month.
Since you can back for just three or for six months, or for a pledge level that includes both the Townbuilder and a subscription, each individual backer will contribute different amounts of money. This means we use the backer number as a rough estimate of our monthly subscriber count, which in return allows us to determine the variety and detail level of a monthly release.
Below you can see the different detail levels that can be unlocked on some example buildings from the Draconic and Aztec theme. 
The roadmap also includes print-ready, support free buildings of all previously created sets. These will be built once, not on a monthly basis, and will be made available to all backers in the same way as the ones from the monthly releases. If you have access to the sets these buildings were built with, you will be able to customize them in the Townbuilder, otherwise, you will only have access to the print-ready version.


Our current Merchant License System is really really simple. You pay 35€ per month and you can sell as many prints of Townbuilder buildings as you want.
This does include all the print-ready buildings that we will create with this Kickstarter.
For more information, check out our License Agreement.
If you want to become a Townbuilder Merchant, check out our store!

As you may know, we have opened the Townbuilder up to external content. This means that we implement models by other creators as well as our users into the Townbuilder.
If you want to know more about this, and want to suggest a creator to us, or get your models into the Townbuilder, send us a message via partners@townsmith.de.

We are Townsmith. This sentence meant a lot to us when we launched our very first Kickstarter over a year ago. And it only continued to grow in meaning when the Kickstarter exploded beyond all expectations on the second attempt. Since then, our team has grown, and so has the responsibility of all of us.
We are very happy to say that we still have the same spirit that originally brought us to this.
We are just a group of nerds who love DnD and 3D printing and creating cool tools for our hobby!


If you want to get in touch with us, the best way is via Discord. We have a very active server with over 1800 users. Feel free to join our community, we are always happy to help you out!
We also post regular updates on Instagram and Facebook.
And then, of course, you should subscribe to our Youtube Channel if you want to get notified whenever we make more user guides.
If you have business-inquiries or want to talk about collaborations in general, please send us an email at business@townsmith.de
If you are interested in becoming a partner and getting your models in the Townbuilder, please contact us via partners@townsmith.de
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have now almost fulfilled one of the biggest digital Kickstarters in the 3D printing scene.
We have gone through the insane challenge of getting a company of 10 people up and running. And it has been running cleanly for about 4 months now (Our initial Kickstarter launched 7 months ago).

We have a team of 5 artists and 1 technician working on getting hundreds of models in the Townbuilder and Tom and I are always available to fix any technical issues that might come up.
And we are ready to expand our team if we reach higher stretch goals and the funding is there. If this system makes 50k a month, rest assured that most of it will directly influence the amount and quality of the models we make, while the rest will go into research and development for the next builder. Wait did I just spoil that we are coding another custom builder? No one reads this section anyway, won't do any harm. For the few of you that do keep posted and look for some green in the wild of our website, you might find some hints soon ;)

Still, there are some risks we simply cannot account for:
A) Longevity. We survived the 'valley of death', that destroys so many start-ups. However, we still cannot guarantee how long the service will live. This Kickstarter is meant to provide us much more safe planning for the next 6 months, but who knows how much money we will make with this system afterward. And if it doesn't pay for the artists, we will not be able to continue the subscriptions.

B) Times of uncertainty. We all know that 2020 just ended, and it taught us, that it can always get worse. So if the world collapses into an economic crisis, a war breaks out or half of our team dies, we will simply not be able to recover. Stuff like this will cause this project to fail since we just don't have millions on the side or 200 employees.

campaign.story:
Welcome to Novus Landing - a seedy, dangerous spaceport on the edge of the galaxy!

This is the third 3D STL Kickstarter I have created in the world of "The Ignis Quadrant". This Kickstarter provides support-free minis, scatter terrain, space ships of all sizes, vehicles, and more for you to produce at home on your FDM or resin 3D printer. Rewards are for digital STL files to print the products shown and described in this campaign. Rewards are split into three categories: Scatter/Terrain,  Space Ships/Vehicles, and Minis - designed to be used together or independently, and all for normal tabletop gaming scale (28-32mm). All these models should work great for games like Starfinder, Star Wars Legion, Fifth Age (5e), Dark Matter (5e), and Cyberpunk games like Infinity (Note that each of those games listed  have all rights reserved, and this campaign is not affiliated or associated with those brands or trademarks).

** PLEASE NOTE - This Kickstarter is for digital files (STLs) to make all these items on your own home 3D printer - these are not physical goods **

**NEW BACKERS** - This project is successfully funded, and ALL the 15 planned stretch goals have been unlocked! There's over 70 support-free minis,  12 larger vehicles/ships, and 175+ scatter STLs included!
-- click to view zoomable high-res version. Photos are a mix of resin and FDM prints. Some content shown may be part of stretch goals --
This project includes a large collection of thematic minis including aliens, creatures, characters, NPCs, androids, drones, and more!
High-quality miniatures, suitable for resin-level detail but also great quality on FDM printers
 NO supports are needed for any of these miniatures, in resin or FDM. This is accomplished by smart posing and design, and slicing/keying where needed.
All models have been test printed and ready to drop on print bed and go.
All minis are included in based versions (pictured below), and also unbased for you to base yourself, use in dioramas, etc. Where split/keyed versions are needed, complete versions are also offered for those that want them. Some are designed to use with flight bases, such as these free ones I have on Thingiverse or the great ones by LITKO . I also released all the mini bases from this project for free HERE. 
WHY SUPPORT-FREE? Support-free is not just for FDM printing, it works GREAT for resin too. Support-free designs have many benefits, including being generally harder to break during travel and play (thicker components, merged geometry), less prone to print failure, and less (if any) cleanup and post-processing. You can throw a bunch on your printer, walk away, and come back confident - and get more models on your table faster!

The minis range in size from small creatures, to HUGE alien beasts. Scale is roughly 32mm (similar in size to Reaper Bones). The below image shows renders of all the models included with the minis set, and will be updated as stretch goals are unlocked.
-- click to view high-res zoomable version --
-- click for high-res zoomable version --
---------------------------------------
Every space port needs some space ships! This project includes many space ships of various types and sizes - ranging from large, multi floor ships to small, sleek fighters. All ships are designed to print and assemble on FDM printers of most sizes, and designed to open for easy play and detailed interiors (many of the ships and vehicles will fit on resin printers as well). There's also many other interesting vehicles to help flesh out your space sport and scifi locations. They are all sized for play similar to the minis and terrain (28-32mm). Like everything in this Kickstarter, the vehicles print support-free, with the exception of a few odd-shaped pieces like window glass. Check em out:
-- click to view high-res zoomable version --
-- click to view high-res zoomable version --
---------------------------------------
This project has all kinds of fun, modular terrain and scenery to build a wealth of different environments like cantinas,  warehouses, landing pads, gambling dens, outdoor markets, and more. It's far-future Scifi in theme, but much is styled to work great with near-future Cyberpunk as well. All items print support free, and are split/designed/optimized for easy printing, painting, and assembly (if needed). The below image shows renders of all the models in some sample configurations included with the scatter set & all-in pledge levels, and will be updated as stretch goals are unlocked:
-- click to view high-res zoomable version --
-- click to view zoomable high-res version --
---------------------------------------
I have all kinds of stretch goals planned - enough to nearly triple the core reward content! You can see what's unlocked in the graphic below. Unless otherwise noted, the models that are unlocked are in the previews above. Some stretch goals will be mini focused, some scatter, some a big vehicle, and others a mix - but I am attempting to balance the added stuff overall.
[UPDATE: all stretch goals have been unlocked, nearly tripling the rewards content! ]
---------------------------------------
Who doesn't like free stuff? There's many free items released, and more coming, to sweeten the pot and give you something to print while the KS is in progress. 
I have released my second set of SCIFI DUNGEONSTICKS, which you can download and print right now. You can access all the other free releases in THIS THINGIVERSE COLLECTION. In addition, all the bases I have designed for this campaign are available for free HERE (which match my last free set of SCIFI BASES). The previous free/bonus models from my last scifi project, The Ignis Quadrant are also perfect test examples of the quality of what's in this project, available HERE.

NOTE: Thingiverse has been flakey lately - if things aren't loading for you, you can download the free preview files and bases in Dropbox HERE. 

Also I teamed up with Ben over at 2nd Dynasty to offer a sweet discount for his huge, epic starships! Click the banner below to visit his MMF store and use the code NovusLandingShips for 30% off, until Feb 28, 2021.
--------------------------------------
As the universe of The Ignis Quadrant has continued to grow beyond my first two scifi STL kickstarters, I decided to create and Kickstart a professionally-drawn comic book series as well! The first 2 issues (Chapter #0 and Chapter #1) are released, with the next chapter coming soon. Many of the characters and environments in this project are reflected in the comic book. If you're a scifi fan (which we assume you are, since you're here!) we absolutely encourage you to check out the comic. You can read the free chapter #0 online for free RIGHT HERE, and buy the digital issue #1 RIGHT HERE
--------------------------------------
My name is Evan Carothers, and I am a 3D designer and tabletop game accessory creator with hundreds of designs released via Thingiverse (ecaroth) and through my premium design company (EC3D). This is my 8th Kickstarter, and any of my thousands of customers can tell you about my track record of easy-to-print models - delivered on time. My skill and love for design has grown out of my passion for tabletop gaming, technology, and 3D printing. I design much of the content myself and work with many other great designers and artists to put these projects together. This is my third Scifi project but it's gonna be epic! You can take a look through my previous projects to get a feel for my team's design aesthetic, or check out some customer reviews. I am a tabletop gamer at heart, and all models are  printed, and often painted, by myself before being released.

Participating Modelers, Artists, Painters, and Printers
Credit to these awesome folks who helped this all come together!

Joshua Black, Sebastiano Di Grazia, Vitaliy Deaf, Ben Southall (Yasashii Kyojin Studio),  Ryan Calhoun (Cephalopod Studios), Povilas Selila, Alexander Buryak, Julia Kuznetsova (PolyGrimm), and Ulises Virgen.
Add-ons allow you to get additional awesome stuff at a great discount, and help push even further to unlock stretch goals! My previous projects have all been fantasy, but I know plenty of gamers play both scifi and fantasy, so I decided to offer them regardless. To get add-ons, just increase your pledge level by the amount indicated for whichever add-ons you would like. Once the KS closes I will be using a pledge manager (BackerKit) to help you finalize you add-ons. You can increase you pledge on KS now to help fund stretch goals, or get these after the campaign closes.

To add any STL stretch goals you must back the campaign at a level that includes STLs. If you only wish to
 The Terra Conflict - My most recent 3D printable Kickstarter, full of space-combat scale ships, creatures, terrain, and more for epic space battles and encounters. This add-on is equivalent to what's included in the '3D Printable STL Files' pledge level of The Terra Conflict, including unlocked stretch goals ($30 add-on for the base set, and $42 for the base set + both add-on fleets).
 The Ignis Quadrant: My first foray into scifi, featuring support-free minis, tons of vehicles and lots of scatter terrain for all your scifi RPG and wargaming needs! The Ignis Quadrant - The add-ons are is equivalent to what's included in all-in pledge level, (including unlocked stretch goals): Minis, Terrain/Scatter, or Vehicles (1 set for $25) or ALL IN (all 3 sets for $50).
 Empire of Scorching Sands: My last sprawling campaign, featuring Arabian/Persian/Egyptian/desert terrain/scatter, monsters, and minis - Empire of Scorching Sands - the add-ons are equivalent to the what's included in that campaign (including stretch goals): Terrain/scatter only ($20 add-on), Minis only ($20 add-on), or ALL IN ($30 add-on).
 Wilds of Wintertide: A chilly, northern project featuring icy, arctic tundra, terrain/scatter, monsters, and minis - Wilds of Wintertide - the add-ons are equivalent to the what's included in that campaign (including stretch goals): Terrain/scatter only ($18 add-on), Minis only ($18 add-on), or ALL IN ($25 add-on).
 A Den of Alien Evil - Everything from the first volume of my "Community (Treasure)Chest" series - Mind Horror scenery, terrain, and minis. Check it out the content from the original campaign HERE ($10 add-on).
 Secret of the Crimson Troupe - Everything from the second volume of my "Community (Treasure)Chest" series - A wandering troupe with a dark secret! Check it out the content from the original campaign HERE ($15 add-on).
 The Holy Order of Ash - Everything from the third volume of my "Community (Treasure)Chest" series - A dark holy order! Check it out the content from the original campaign HERE ($15 add-on).
 Depths of Savage Atoll: A sprawling campaign, featuring nautical, jungle, pirate, and undersea minis and environs - Depths of Save Atoll - the add-ons are equivalent to the what's included in that campaign (including stretch goals): Terrain/scatter only ($35 add-on), Minis only ($35 add-on), or ALL IN ($65 add-on).
 Skyless Realms: The races and places below the surface, from my previous campaign Skyless Realms  - the add-ons are equivalent to what's included in that campaign (including stretch goals): Terrain only ($40 add-on), Minis only ($35 add-on), or ALL IN ($55 add-on).
 Forest of Oakenspire - Everything from the core reward and stretch goals from my first Kickstarter Forest of Oakenspire at a great discount ($40 add-on).
 All EC3D Premium Sets - The full collection of all 12 previously released premium sets - over $100 value, as seen for sale on Hero's Hoard ($50 add-on)
 Individual EC3D Premium Sets - Chose any number of my EC3D scenery sets from my previously released premium set collection - substantial value over retail price, as seen for sale on Hero's Hoard ($5 per-set add-on)
** Please note ** - all the add-on items above can be purchased right now for a higher price on heroshoard.com or late pledge pages for those campaigns, but if you are willing to wait until this campaign closes to receive the files you can get a great discount AND help unlock more stuff for this current campaign.

I have an official licensed printer program for my 3D sets, along with my partner at Hero's Hoard, which allows commercial physical resellers with a 10% commission on sales. Anybody can signup for that license, and sell the models from this campaign under that license, and I will not be doing specific merchant tiers for this campaign. So to sell these files (and other non-exclusive EC3D sets) you just need to signup for that resale program and back this campaign to receive the files.
Everybody hates waiting, and many people have been burned by poorly designed files and broken delivery timelines in previous kickstarters from other vendors. This is not the case with my campaigns. All core models, and many stretch goals, area already finalized and test printed - and the majority of files will be ready for delivery the second the funds clear after the Kickstarter finishes (usually 2 weeks after the date the campaign ends). I will be finalizing and releasing the remaining items as fast as humanly possible, with a goal of 90 days *MAX* after this Kickstarter ends for delivery - which is something I have successfully done for all my previous Kickstarters. Please note, historically I wait until I have released everything from one project to launch another, but I have a fantasy STL project launching right after this one, which is smaller in scope and already completed, and I'm confident will not slow my planned release schedule for Novus Landing.

Disclaimer & Printing Requirements

To get the most out of the printable parts from this Kickstarter, you will need to have a well-tuned 3D printer. For terrain/scatter and FDM printer capable of printing at a minimum .2mm layer height (ideally <= .16mm), such as an Ender 3.  Parts are cut to small pieces to facilitate printing. All designs for terrain are cut and keyed to fit on a 200x200mm print bed.  For minis, a resin printer is ideal and all mini models are cut/keyed (only as needed) to fit on standard sized smaller resin print beds (such as an Anycubic Photon), with the exception of a few VERY large minis and some large spaceship parts. Minis will print on FDM printers as well - for a few of the more challenging models you might need to slow the print down a bit, but no supports will be needed.

Every part is test printed by myself and repaired to be manifold and ready to drop on your slicer - however, In the event that any issues with the files get past my own QA testing and process, and my other test printers, I will make every effort to fix the file and remedy the situation as soon as possible. I use Dropbox for file delivery so I can push updates/fixes. My number one goal is to make some awesome, unique designs you can have a ton of fun with on your tabletop!

campaign.story:
Introducing a precisely digitally hand-recreated reproduction of the next Cotta's almanac deck full of history, and for the third time, strongly touched by Schiller's works, continuing a year after the previous green and the blue one, which was the first published complete transformation playing card deck in the world! 
The yellow "Wallenstein" deck is the third in a series of six famous transformation playing card decks we plan to release... This third Cotta's almanac playing cards deck was originally published in 1807. It draws on aspects from another Schiller's work - the famous historical drama Wallenstein and the theme of the 30 Years' War.
"Numbered" Limited Edition Displayed (Whole Metallic Gold-Inked Tuck)
 Features:
Printed by USPCC on Classic Stock
Poker Size
Embossed (Linen) Finish 
52 Cards + 2 Extra 17th-century Jokers + 2 Extra Collectible 16th-century Art Cards 
Metallic Ink On Box & Card Backs (Both Versions of Tucks and Card Backs inside) 
Custom Seals - Numbered and Standard 
Puzzle Image on all Tuck Spines of the Series (Inking Vary by Tuck Version) 
Digitally Hand-Recreated and Designed by Azured Ox
Produced By Will Roya
After the success of the first blue 1805 and the second green 1806 Cotta's almanac decks, again we come with two versions of the third yellow 1807 Cotta's deck limited edition - the "Numbered" and the "Standard".
As campaigns before, we are limiting this 3rd "Numbered" deck to only 1,000 copies of tuck which is the whole gold-inked with custom numbered seals. Additional "Standard" limited edition decks are created just with a slight difference on tuck designed with dark and gold ink combination and the same custom seals (non-numbered). Both versions will include the same gold metallic inked card back design inside of the tuck box. 
There are many historical values in the series of decks...
That's why the entire 6 deck series is in many ways designed by Azured Ox to meet collector's demand as a "collection of historical books" with their mysteries and secrets hidden inside up to your findings...
Series of decks will be produced with the piece of puzzle image on each tuck "book" spine (left side of the box) to create together a nice display of the Tuebingen monument surroundings, where the idea for Cotta's decks was born. 
Puzzle Spine Image "Digital Demonstration" to present Ink Combinations of Both Tuck Versions
If you are interested in more information about historical details with a profound and beautiful story behind Cotta's Almanac playing cards creation and idea, or about the famous and noble people connected to these unique transformation playing card decks, you can find reading after scrolling down this project page. 
The design of both versions of Cotta's limited edition tuck boxes, the standard and the numbered, created by Azured Ox, have been inspired by the old books and published writers' work using the gold ink on their covers as well as combined with the dark ink.
Inking and Tuck Design Inspired by Old Books
Unexplained stories, hidden mysteries, secrets...
Much of historical happenings, influences, and activities would find a place in the Cotta decks, including events in the life of Cotta's own family and notable figures like Schiller and Goethe. Other important influences include the literature, art, history, politics (e.g. Napoleon's invasion), and religious reforms of the time, which all served as an important context to shape the art in the decks themselves... 
 Third almanac deck: "Wallenstein" (Year 1807) 
After the first blue deck themed on Joan of Arc play by Schiller, and the second green deck themed on Jean Racine's plays, which were translated into the German language by Schiller, here in the third yellow deck, again the images on the court cards are the characters from another Schiller's work, the three parts historical drama play Wallenstein centered around the 30 Years' War (1618–1648). In Wallenstein were embodied the fateful forces of his time.
The central figure - Albrecht Wenzel Eusebius von Wallenstein, sometimes von Waldstein (24 September 1583 – 25 February 1634), is depicted as the King of Hearts. 
He was a prince of the German Empire and a Bohemian (westernmost region of Czech republic) military leader and statesman who fought on the Catholic side during the Thirty Years' War of which he was a major figure. 
He belonged to the men of the Renaissance and the world of the Baroque, but also he stood above these categories as an exceptional individual. Raised bilingually, he went beyond Czech or German nationality, beyond Catholic or Protestant denominations.
His successful martial career made him one of the richest and most influential men in the Holy Roman Empire by the time of his death. Wallenstein became the supreme commander of the armies of the Habsburg Emperor Ferdinand II.
For his successes, Wallenstein became an Imperial count palatine and made himself ruler of the lands of the Duchy of Friedland in northern Bohemia.
"Wallensten Herzog zu Friedland" (Lettered on King of Heart Court Card)
It's not all just about Schiller's famous works...
As the first blue and the second green deck before, also this third yellow deck was threaded by majestic and noble roots, nay of one more person... Besides the noble publisher of the deck, Johann Friedrich Cotta, there were two other persons involved in the graphical part of this deck creation. 
Johann Friedrich Cotta (April 27, 1764 - December 29, 1832)
For the third time, again, cards were designed and stipple engraved by Countess Mary Day von Jennison-Walworth (sometimes spelled with a single 'n'). Her maiden name was Beauclerk, and she was the wife of Count Francis Jenison Walworth (1764–1824).
Probably, she was creating illustrations for decks in Stuttgart (detected from letter communication addressed to her mother in Britain that contained writings about the Cotta's decks...), and so there in Stuttgart, she might put additional historical value into her playing cards creation by mutual cooperation due to her artistic passion & connections network - images on cards of this deck were mostly based on sketches and preliminary brush drawings by well-known Christian Wilhelm von Faber du Faur from Stuttgart. 
Not only from a noble baron family with French roots of ancestors, he was an army officer, soldier, and lieutenant in the 25th Division, which was the Württemberg unit during the Napoleonic Wars, and also a painter focused on the war theme. 
His involvement is indicated by writing at the base of the 10 of Clubs, which says "Christian Faber du Faur inv. et del." 
Six Unique Different Card Back Patterns Designed, with Regard to Card Handling, Individually for Each of the Cotta's Deck Year Almanacs. 
Classic Style Borderless Full-Bleed Card Back Design with Luxury Feeling and Metallic Ink
The Same Gold Metallic Ink Card Back Design for Both Editions of the Cotta's Deck
Aces
The publisher's name was placed on the Ace of Clubs as follows: "A Tubinge chez J. G. Cotta, Libraire."
Spades
Hearts

Diamonds
In contrast to previous Cotta's decks issues where the court cards were designated with the words "Valet", "Dame", and "Roi", which are the French terms corresponding to the Jack, Queen, and King, here on the court cards of this 3rd issue, Jack and Queen are not described, only King is described with Crown at upper Left.
The central figure of Albrecht von Wallenstein, the Duke of Friedland who served the Holy Roman Emperor in the Thirty Year's War, is represented as the King of Hearts. 
Also depicted are his general Christian von Ilow ("Illo", King of Spades), and his lieutenant Octavio Piccolomini (King of Clubs). Instead of following his intelligence, Wallenstein foolishly followed his astrologer Baptista Seni (Jack of Hearts). By his many schemes involving multiple countries, Wallenstein eventually found himself in a position where nobody could trust him. Piccolomini was one of Wallenstein's assassins, along with the English captain Walter Devereux (Jack of Clubs). Other contemporaries of Wallenstein that are depicted include his wife, the Duchess of Friedland (Queen of Hearts).

Some characters blur the line between fiction and reality. This includes Countess Terzky (Queen of Spades), who in real life was Wallenstein's wife's sister, but takes on fictional actions in Schiller's play. Wallenstein's secretary Newman (Jack of Spades) also makes an appearance, but in the deck becomes the fictional cavalry captain and assistant of Count Terzky. Max Piccolomini (King of Diamonds), the son of the killer Octavio Piccolomini, is also a fictitious character. The same is true of Wallenstein's princess and daughter Thekla (Queen of Diamonds), her servant von Rosenberg (Jack of Diamonds), and her lady-in-waiting Fraulein Neubrunn (Queen of Clubs).

The story behind these playing cards, which probably conceal most of the world's playing card secrets, begins in Tübingen, a city in southwest Germany.
The idea behind the concept of Cotta's transformation decks was to create a series of six decks on an annual basis from 1805-1811. Each deck would focus on a different theme...
Forming a "Card Almanac" (Karten Almanach), each card in the deck would represent one of the 52 weeks in a calendar year. At the time it was popular to print various almanacs, which were special pocketbooks for the new year, and often included a short poem or quote for each week of the calendar year. It was a logical move to connect each of these 52 weeks with playing cards.
Original illustrations were fiddling artworks - manually stipple engraved & etched on copper plates
 The famous Cotta's publishing house... 

The friendship that gave birth to the idea of Cotta's transformation playing card almanac decks...
The color of each tuck box created by Azured Ox has been inspired by Goethe's experimental optic and color theory, since Goethe was an important contemporary of Cotta, along with Schiller. (Goethe's deepest immersion into colors was during Cotta's decks issuing.)

campaign.story:
Pitch Line
3D modular printable computer cases that can be printed on most 3D printers part by part with a printer bed as small as 100x100x100 mm. 
Objective
Enable as many people as possible with the smallest of 3D printers to print and customize their own computer case. Backers will not only get the stl files, which take printer tolerances into account, they will also get the fusion 360 files, which created the stl files.
First Files
Backers will be able to print their own Mini ITX case in either a regular or slim form factor. When printed, backers will be able to attach a power supply and a motherboard to get basic functionality. Backers will also have the option to attach a graphics card to the outside for the slim form factor or a 2.5 inch hard drives for the regular form factor.
Slim Case Design
Regular Case Design
Note: Dimensions will differ slightly based off of the printer and any changes made to the original design.

Included in the Base Tier
Plain panels, which can be used for the top, bottom, and front of the case.
Panels onto which an SFX PowerSupply can be attached
Circular power button panel for the regular size and square shaped power supply button for the slim case.
Front face plates for the motherboard to attach.
Corner components, which connect the base, panels, and motherboard plate.
Base for which all panels and corners attach to.
Slim Case Design
Regular Case Design 
Note: The base width and height per part is only 90mm and must be printed 4 times to make the 180mm by 180mm base.
Graphics Card Mount (Optional)
Mount an optional low profile graphics card for an improved gaming experience.
Note: Using a  card bigger than 180mm or 2 PCIe slots in size may be too heavy for the plastic piece, which the graphics card screws into.
Hard Drive Catty (Optional)
Attach 2.5" drives by print out the hard drive catty panels so that you can add terabytes of storage to your tiny build.
Note: It will be required to buy M3 x 1/4 screws. 

Timeline
July: Free solutions for printable computer cases for an emulation PC were not acceptable. If the print job should fail printing would have to restart which would result in loss of material and time.
August: Sketches were drawn for a modular case design. Began a rough 3D draft and opened up an Instagram page.
September: Felt that the 3D design was pretty solid. Started printing out components to have the first printed version of the case.
October: Created a second slimmer design of the original regular case.
November: Kicked off the Kickstarter campaign.
December: Allow backers to download the Mini ITX case.
January: Wrap up the Kickstarter.

Future Plans
With these first products, we hope to gauge the amount of public interest for new printable case designs which we would like to produce. Other cases in the future would encompass support for Micro ATX, ATX, eATX, etc. as well as full enclosures with the continual goal of modularity in mind.

It isn't easy to design a case within the confines of a small print bed. Working through the problem via planning and experimentation allows us to be creative to solve the challenges for our customers so they don't have to.

campaign.story:
When you were younger and happier, you often spent hours in the woods, sitting quietly and drawing. Over time, you did it less and less: first homework, then the stress of a new job, then...you just didn’t. You were good at drawing once. Never great, but good—and it brought you so much joy. Joy is hard for you to come by these days.

So begins your journey in below, a solo journaling game about getting lost in a strange, uncomfortable place. Over the course of 10 days, you'll explore a remote area you find yourself trapped in. In responding to the journaling prompts, players are encouraged to draw parts of their responses, even if you don't think that your drawing skills are good. This is a game for you about falling out of your comfort zone.
It's important that players understand that below addresses many topics that could be upsetting to players. The narrative of the game addresses depression through metaphor, and as such, for players who aren't in a good place mentally, it may not be the game for you right now.
In below, you play someone exploring an area they used to love but no longer feel connected to. At the end of the first day, you fall into a dark, unfamiliar region and cannot find a way out. Over the course of the ten days of the game, you'll keep a record of your explorations through words and images as you endure.
Content Warnings: below addresses, through metaphor, depression and the disconnection that comes along with it. There are prompts that address falling, being lost, not having food or water, nearly drowning, and harm to an animal caused by predation and its resulting suffering.

The game will be emailed to you on December 21st, the darkest day of the year. (The rewards say January, but that's because Kickstarter doesn't allow the rewards to be promised for the same month as the campaign.)
The writing for the game is finished, and I'm currently doing final playtesting on it. It will be ready to go before the end of the campaign.
In terms of art, there's only the cover image for Fergus to do, and they've already taken care of that.
Fergus Ferguson (any pronouns) - Cover Art - is a student and artist, dual majoring in computer science and fine arts at Tufts University. When they are not studying or drawing, they like to play tabletop games, read sci-fi, and tell everyone how great their betta fish is. They can be found on Twitter (@fergusfergyferg).
Doug Levandowski (he/him) - Design, Writing & Layout - is a teacher and game designer from New Jersey. He has worked on larger RPGs such as Kids on Bikes, Teens in Space, and Kids on Brooms as well as Kickstarter-delivered ones like The Wishing Sigil, Agents of Dice-Ception, and, most recently, Arcane Zoo. He can be found on Twitter (@levzilla).

campaign.story:
Thumbies : Thumbmart is a one to eight player game. After each player decides which Survivor Character they wish to be, the group selects a Survivor Chapter.
Every Survivor Chapter drives a unique story, prepares the board and outlines directives. Some chapters are solitary incidents, and some chapters are part of expansive story arcs that follow a survivor on their saga.
Game play gets very hands on after this point.
Each player will gather their first personal bit of biometry by measuring their hand span from thumb to little finger with the built-in ruler. This information is used by the ZOMBIE Framework which is expressed in greater detail further down the page in Ground Breaking Elements. The ZOMBIE Framework is the way this game connects YOU to the board and creates an intricate and dynamic gaming experience without troubling the player with complex calculations or classic pen and dice game mechanics.
In this game I decided to call the Zombie opposition 'Thumbies' as a tribute to this unique biometric system. Using the Survivor Chapter and everyone's hand spans the players will populate the board with some Thumbies that were hanging around before the players entered the scene.
Players use a different Hand Span to determines how many items a player can carry in their inventory.
During your quest to survive you will collect hundreds of useful and sometimes not so useful items. Players will need to determine what items they need to keep and which items they must discard or trade. Discovery and circumstances play an important role during every session – what might have been the game-winning resource management strategy for one session becomes the tragic miscalculation for another. This is one reason why chapters are so addictive and re-playable.
The game begins once players finish agreeing who gets which items from the load out deck.
Found item cards are obtained from Thumbies.
And Board Stock Cards are item cards obtained from specific storage locations situated around the game board.
These locations are often locked and require keys or codes to open.
Cards with expendable supply like guns, ammunition and first aid use a tally system situated on their edges instead of small resource tokens that always seem to go missing between game sessions.
The tally system on the cards interface with your player board. This is where a player stores their active items, player and survivor card and keeps track of their level and current health.
As players make kills the Thumbie tokens are placed in the Player board to count levels, unlocking Survivor Cards. Players draw their Survivor Card at random sometimes finding that a good trait has materialized or a disadvantageous trait has developed. Don't worry, at higher levels player's will have a chance to replace survivor cards as their character becomes more battle hardened.
During game play players try and meet the victory conditions of their Survivor Chapter while pesky Thumbies pour into the game area using the ZOMBIE Framework.
Sometimes unanticipated events are drawn instead of items making hordes of Thumbies pour in or the dreaded All-thumbs Monster to amalgamate. Such examples of events can prove to be a tipping point for survival, and necessitate the groups consensuses to change strategy or perish in disorganized confusion.
When a player gets hit they attribute the damage on their player board condition monitor moving the token on their handy player board.
Thumbies transcends the static game experience again by placing your personal biometrics on the line. The player board condition monitor corresponds to your characters ability to move and function in-game. The result is transmitting game damage into the allowable finger combinations a player is permitted to utilized for actions like, movement, rescuing and attacking.
Using the ZOMBIE Framework™ Thumbies® has broken away from traditional Hex or grid based combat systems liberating the combat experience using an organic versatility. Even attacking is hand rationalized!
Tabletop beginners and veterans will enjoy the quick resolution and sublime game mechanics of Thumbies. And those who are truly paying attention for the high stakes pay-off can capitalize on such game changers with the Build Plan system facilitated by random draw and careful inventory management.
Thumb-mart is the first step on our ambitious journey to bring you more game sets in the Thumbies Series. This game set support hundreds of hours of gaming and exportation, character building and memorable close shaves. It is our goal to provide the most fun and creative gaming experience we can muster; and so Thumbies : Thumbmart was also designed to be integrated with future game sets. Each a stand-alone collection in their own right every set has the ability to link to other sets forming a veritable landscape of epic game play using the ZOMBIE Framework.
Two such game sets are already in the works and will be announced early next year. Linking is an option to uncover more story, unlock tiered difficulty chapters and experience the option of longer epic game-play using the special Aftermath Challenges.
1 Player Solo up to 8 Players Team Game Play
Thumbies® is engineered to respond to any number of players from a single individual up to eight players using measuring elements obtained at the beginning of game play.
Innovative Player Board
The player board is a cluster of ideas made possible by a tri-layer board developed to alleviate the need for counting chits, counters or pen and paper record keeping. Rationed or expended items use a notch based tally system built into the board keeping the item card in place so a visual representation of its stock can be tallied. Hollows keep a record of character level development with overlapping summaries to track advancement and save space. And the center hand print image with its hollows serve as a reminder to the player for which two fingers to biometrically use when modifying their movement span if and when their character is hurt.
ZOMBIE Framework Whitepaper
The integrated math and subsequent engineering model that governs the entire game is called the Z.O.M.B.I.E. Framework ® a smart acronym representing the systems larger more technical name : the (Zone Operational Movement Biometrically Intrinsic Engine). This framework's chief founding purpose is to cloak complex statistics by providing an auto-calculated operation that can be interpolated into actionable game play mechanics like movement, combat, challenges, and other RPG derivatives like abilities. The effective cloaking provides the satisfaction of a statistically rich environment while lessening the computational aspect tabletop games often encounter when rationalizing elaborate game play. This effort, of course, was designed to elevate the gaming experience so players can focus on feelings and fun and let the Framework do the work.
ZOMBIE FRAMEWORK ELEMENT 1 : Board Contour and Features
The geometry of the board is made using a series of underpinning theorems that relate to the playable area. Accounting for any number of players between 1 and 8, the individual variance in hand sizes, given trip-related journeys and coverage of selected game play mechanics; token size and weight, the coefficient of friction and zone based occupancy optimization. Mission instructions and card randomization complement these rules... and sometimes break them, thus making up a finely tuned and abstract difficulty tool.
ZOMBIE FRAMEWORK ELEMENT 2 : Hand Biometrics
To increase the feel of player relatability to the environment, the ZOMBIE Framework took hand-measurements and turned them into operational character mechanics. The system could have used grid or hexed based models for movement and action resolution but that would have drastically reduced the work achieved in board design; especially considering the effort placed in accounting for the distribution of hand averages in contours and features. Furthermore it would have left out a delicious morsel of biopsychiatry that will be mentioned further in the paper.
Thus, hand biometrics are used to rationalize 100% of character statistics and activities making for an organic feel and a distinct and hitherto unimagined innovation in tabletop gaming. In Thumbies® digit length, distance between tips, segment lengths, grouping widths, span flexibility, closed and open palm sizes are all utilized biometrics. And due to the unique anatomy of the opposable thumb saddle-joint a special design was employed in this system that sets at the fulcrum of Thumbies® giving life to the game and its name-sake.
ZOMBIE FRAMEWORK ELEMENT 3 : Board Based Assist
The ZOMBIE Framework does not require a game master or any user to move zombies one by one or do any ancillary accounting typically found in classical RPG and tabletop systems. Players can effectively move hundreds of tokens (zombies in this case) with one motion and the aforementioned contours makes them disperse in a meaningful way to create bottlenecking, pincer attacks and the type of movement we all might expect from a massive crowd of thronging creatures
Culturally speaking the ZOMBIE Framework also acknowledges both the classic definition of zombie (Night of the Living Dead model) as slow shambling throngs but is versatile and robust enough to include other zombie types such as exploding, area effect, running attacking and gargantuation. These all appear in gameplay depending on the survivor chapter, and more continue to be invented as the next boards are designed and the script continues.
ZOMBIE FRAMEWORK ELEMENT 4 : Biopsychiatry
The ZOMBIE Framework gives the player an impression of survival because you can physically fight-it-out and make attempts to outmaneuver their foe. Players are connected to the game by the anatomy of their hand and associate their characters' limitations with themselves identifying with game play stronger than dice-deck-dial based systems.
We as humans are inextricably tied to learning with our hands and involving our hands when we think and do even when hands are not being employed. This cognitive fact has a biopsychiatry effect that only became realized during the alpha testing of the game. Simply put we felt more invested and tried to survive harder as if our life was on the line. The non-passivity of the game through the frequency of hand use was making us players emotionally chemically invested in the game and not just because we wanted to win but because we thought we could against any and all odds - a thing I realized falls off when you count the odds in traditional dice-deck-dial games. Making Thumbies® both a fun and fantastic gaming experience and a truly groundbreaking discovery.
Exact shipping will be calculated and charged after the campaign closes. A few months before the game ships we will contact you through the pledge manager one last time regarding shipping to double check our records to make sure we get the game to right address. Shipping will be charged all at one time. We are doing it this way to try and save on costs to you because our sources say that prices may lessen as the Covid-19 crisis lessens.

campaign.story:
Project Astrala 3d render
Project Astrala 3d render
Prototype Project Astrala
Prototype Project Astrala
Welcome to Project Astrala, My name is Lantz Jones and I am here to get support and funding from people just like you who wish to see my product become a reality, so lets get started. Project Astrala began as just a dream, I was tired of seeing overpriced off the shelf bluetooth speakers that catered toward looking fancy and cool instead of focusing on the sound quality. Early 2020 I was able to see my dream begin its steps to infancy as I was able to purchase my first 3d printer, mind you i had no idea at the time on how to effectively manage and use a 3d printer, let alone create a 3d file. So my information journey began. I spent weeks researching as much as i could on 3d printers until finally I felt comfortable enough to try to 3d print a file I had found on Thingiverse, now being the slight nerd that I am, my first 3d print was the Pokemon Lapras. After that successful 3d print I went on to finding more things I wanted to 3d print, but after a time I decided I wanted to try my hand at designing my own 3d files. That is is when I remembered about the off the shelf bluetooth speaker issue I had. So after tons of more research I jumped into designing my own bluetooth speaker, and being as I had already had a background in home and car audio I already had a leg up on where I wanted to go with my idea. So after several trial and errors and wasted filament I finally had what I had dreamed of, and Project Astrala was born. Now enough backstory lets get on to what you really came here for. Project Astrala is a 3d printed Hifi bluetooth speaker that utilizes a quarter wave transmission line enclosure for dual 2" full range drivers being pushed by a 10w stereo Bluetooth BT 5.0 amp board powered by 3.7v lithium ion battery. Along with a few cosmetic options. But the primary focus is on the sound quality, Project Astrala produces crystal clear, clean audio and can reproduce some lower end bass frequencies that normally would not be heard in a 2" full range driver, thanks to the enclosure style. Now after writing out a full blown essay, I would like to thank you for your future support and for the fact you took the time to read all of this.
Sincerly, Lantz Jones
