campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Van Ryder Games has successfully funded and fulfilled many projects. We learn more and more with each experience. Our goal is to get the product to you, our supporters, as quickly as possible, but we won't sacrifice quality for speed.

There are the usual risks of printing, shipping, customs, and other unintended delays, but you can be sure we will deliver the game to you as promised. Feel free to check our track record or ask any of our returning backers!

A few remarks we want to share with you regarding our approach for our projects, including this one.
1. Communication is of the utmost importance to us. Please ask any and all questions and we will answer as quickly as possible.
2. Our stretch goal items (if any) are determined by us before the campaign begins, in the event all of them are achieved we will not add more as it puts our project timeline and cost at risk.
3. Your comments and feedback are REALLY important to us. If you have an idea, concern, or compliment, please share it with us! We can't promise to implement or act on every idea that comes our way, but we will certainly consider and listen to each one!
4. We pledge to keep a positive attitude regardless of the success or failure of this project and we ask that you do the same.
5. To have fun! Kickstarter projects can be stressful, but these are games and the most important thing is to have FUN!

Please note the following is our policy on pledges and refunds.

Refund Policy

All pledges are final upon the completion of the funding period, however, we may, at our sole discretion, refund your pledge in full if the request is made within two weeks of the end of the campaign. Any request for a refund after more than two weeks has passed, if accepted by us, will be subject to a 10-20% cancellation fee to account for KS fees and our administrative expenses. Please note that, anyone that does not complete the pledge manager by our required deadlines will not be eligible for a refund for any reason, including the assessment of additional shipping fees for expenses related to the delinquency of the backer completing their survey information.

Abandoned Pledges

We require that our pledge manager and/or survey be completed in a timely manner so that we can process orders efficiently and on time. Completing your survey late at any point beyond the deadline we communicate AND/OR failure to pay shipping in a timely manner when the surveys are (re)opened, could result in significant delays in receiving your rewards, additional shipping expense, duties, taxes, or other fees to be paid by you, and you will not be eligible for a refund for any reason. We give plenty of time to complete the survey, so please do so in a timely manner to avoid any inconvenience or delay. Any survey that is not completed within 30 days from final fulfillment (defined as the last date of shipping of KS rewards for your region) will result in your pledge being considered abandoned and any amount pledged will be considered a gift in support of the project.

By pledging to this project you understand the risks, challenges, and pledge terms we have laid out here, and agree to be bound by them. If you do not agree to these terms, please do not pledge for this project and wait for the possibility of the game to become available direct or in the retail market.

updates.update_content:
What is happening with Final Girl?
Hey everyone,  here we are with the June update. Production continues and the factory is looking good to wrap things up on that front soon.  We are waiting back to hear exactly when it will be finished, but I've been told all of the non-printed items (plastics, wood, etc.) are done. Fun fact, it is actually pretty unusual to have those items done before the printed materials, but due to the unique challenges we've had with this project the printed materials (cards, rules, boxes, etc.) will be the last things finished.

First off, we wanted to thank everyone for the support over the last month or so. It was a very difficult time and your love and support meant the world to us. We've done (and are doing) what we needed to do to take care of ourselves, our families, and each other. But as they say, the show must go on.
What is happening with Final Girl?
We are pleased to report that we are more or less back on track with getting this project completed. We made the necessary changes we wanted to make (credits, an FG character name change, and a few other minor details) in response to the events detailed in the previous update and now the manufacturer is back into production to finish everything up for us.

What is happening with Final Girl?
Well first off, thanks for everyone's patience while we waited for and gathered information to make sure we could communicate everything we want to in this update. It has been a busy and often stressful month or so since we last updated. So let's get into it...
Final Girl workstreams:

What is happening with Final Girl?
Well as expected, there is not too much to cover this month in terms of production, so this will be a text-only update.
Final Girl workstreams:

What is happening with Final Girl?
The PPCs (pre-production copies) have arrived, that's what!!!! This is an exciting time and hopefully, you forgive us the few extra days of waiting this month as we wanted to wait for the PPCs to arrive before we posted January's update. We'll get to the PPCs below, but first, let's look at the workstreams.

What is happening with Final Girl?
We are in the thick of it with the manufacturer in terms of the production process. We are keeping a close eye on the logistics environment even though we are still a few months away from shipping - the landscape in that regard isn't great right now, but hopefully, that improves by the time we are ready for freight shipping from the Factory.

What is happening with Final Girl?
Now that all of the files have been provided to the manufacturer, a bit of a waiting game occurs as now it is up to our partners at LongPack to turn our vision into a physical product. We are very excited to now be in this process as it means we are still on schedule and on track!

Muwahahaha! Surprise!
Did we scare you with this surprise update?!?!? Hahaha just kidding, you are probably just excited. 
Well, given the season, we wanted to pop in with a bonus update. There are a lot of reasons to celebrate! For one, tomorrow (Oct. 30) is our self-imposed deadline for finishing up all of the files to be packaged and sent to the manufacturer. This is a huge milestone, and represents the completion of the work (barring any tweaks as a result of our pre-production copy review) by the design and development team. We are going to celebrate this milestone with something really cool, a bit of a surprise... and we need your input! More on that in a minute...
Hey everyone! Another month gone by and a whole ton more work done on this project! Is everyone excited for the Halloween season? Check out this Frightmare Cover!

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Our experienced team members have been involved in the manufacturing phase of many board games including the Dice Throne Franchise, Santorini, Brass: Birmingham & Lancashire, Iron Clays, and of course Steampunk Rally.

Our threshold for component quality is extremely high and our regimented artists hit deadlines with the timing of a Swiss watch. Members of our pre-press team have worked in the print industry for nearly 20 years and are able to work smoothly and efficiently with manufacturers. All art and development is completed and barring any unforeseen hurdles, we will begin manufacturing immediately after the campaign ends.

All this said, it is possible that there may be delays. This is the nature of manufacturing complex and innovative products. In our case, possible delays may be associated with shipping, customs, and manufacturing. The biggest unknown at this point is delays related to COVID-19. While many countries around the globe are currently “reopening”, there is always risk of a second wave, which may cause delays in manufacturing and fulfillment.

We have gone to great lengths to source reliable manufacturing options and set attainable timelines. We have a strong belief in sticking to deadlines, and an even greater belief in transparency. We will therefore ensure that you are informed with our progress and challenges every step of the way.

Thank you for believing in us.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Welcome back to the city, adventurers! Fantasy City Sites and Scenes II is a 48-page (plus cover, inside covers, and back cover) 8.5" x 11" book for gamemasters who are in need of inspiration. The book details sixteen different city locations and offers up a selection of encounter ideas, all of which can be used on their own or added to the content described in the original Fantasy City Sites and Scenes book. (See the original Kickstarter campaign to learn more about the first book. Update on the first book: all PDF and print rewards are complete! The print rewards finished shipping to backers on May 19, 2020.)
Do you already own my other fantasy RPG supplements that were created thanks to the support of Kickstarter backers? Then you're looking for either the $1 (PDF) or $18 (print, U.S. only) reward levels. All of the other listed rewards are for those gamemasters who missed out on my earlier projects. 
 City Sites. The sixteen locations described in the book (each a two-page spread) presents new buildings that may be dropped into your campaign . . . and along with it, the characters and events detailed alongside the building. You won't find a dry collection of statistics and facts in this book. Each entry was written to spark the gamemaster's imagination and provide GMs with just enough to take the idea and make it their own! 
 City Scenes. Pages 36 through 48 (plus the inside back cover of the printed book!) are packed with new day and night encounters. These encounters do not duplicate any found in the original Fantasy City Sites and Scenes book, meaning that this section greatly expands the gamemaster's number of choices when it comes time to randomly select a city encounter.
So that we don't accidentally cause project delays, there will be no stretch goals for this campaign. I'd much rather deliver on schedule than risk running late with delivery of the rewards.
I know that the lack of stretch goals will cause some of you to turn away, but I ask that you keep this in mind: The 52-page PDF reward is only a buck, making this a great deal for any gamemaster who enjoys running city encounters and adventures.
Over 1,700 supporters came together to make the Fantasy City Sites and Scenes campaign a success! (Kickstarter page here.) Did you miss out on the original book project? Now's your chance to score both the original and the second volume at the same time! See the rewards, at right, for more information and to join in!

The Dungeon Crafter's Sketch Book is for the gamemaster who enjoys creating dungeons. (Kickstarter page here.) This 56-page book (60 including the cover, inside covers, and back cover) is filled with page after page of grids (hex or square, see the reward descriptions), space for you to draw your dungeon ideas. Scattered throughout the book are several random tables to inspire you as you create your newest dungeon. There are a limited number of print copies available; please see the reward listing for more information.
Did you miss out on the Kickstarter campaign for A Dozen Sinister Rumors? Now's your chance to grab these 17 different PDFs and expand you collection of GM tools!
If you wish to buy single PDFs, and not all 17 of these titles, you can find each one at DrivethruRPG.
***
Probably the most common question that comes in every few weeks is: "How can I get your books dedicated to the Star Wars newspaper ads of the seventies and eighties?" The books are tough to find, so I am offering a handful of copies in this campaign for those who missed out on these books.
Sample pages from one of the three books. Each is 96 pages, 8.25" square, and hardcover.
I do not run an online store, so that means I rarely offer these books for sale. Still, there have been enough requests this month alone that I felt it was time to list these as a reward in this latest Kickstarter campaign. These are great gifts for fans of the Kenner Star Wars action figures of the seventies and eighties.


***
The bulk of the artwork in this book is used under license from Shutterstock.com, created by Asanee Srikijvilaikul, Larry Jacobsen, koya979, NextMarsMedia, Oliver Denkar, Petrafler, Runa0410, Ryzhkov Sergey. After years of experience with Kickstarter, running and backing projects, combined with decades of experience in publishing, I think _most_ of the largest challenges and risks have been avoided. The book is complete, and all that remains is funding and the project review stage where project supporters are encouraged to crowdsource spotting and correcting the typos that are surely somewhere inside the work.

However, things can go wrong. As an individual, I do not have access to a company to assist with packing and shipping rewards (a friend helps!), and I have no control over life. Everything should ship on schedule, but things can (and sometimes do) go wrong. If something goes off the rails, I will post an update to explain the situation.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
"My husband and I would like to open a mini-golf business and we  would like to hire someone to design us a course. We have asked several  designers like you to propose us something, so whomever designs the best  one is hired!"
Minigolf Designer is a competitive free form puzzle board game for 1 to 5 players that plays in 60 to 90 minutes (around 20 minutes per players).
An example of Hole made out of tiles
In Minigolf Designer, players will compete to collect tiles representing sections of mini golf holes, and arrange them the way they want to form a 9 holes miniature golf course. However, in the end the players will gain more or less victory points depending on certain aspects of their mini golf course, and also depending on the number of people drawn on their mini golf layout.
One of the three Rulers used to present the tiles and hold the turn order
Tiles are proposed to the players ordered from the least to the most valuable tile (depending on the number of victory points that the tile provides), but this order becomes also the player's next turn order.
The game is simple and plays fast, as players do only one thing during their turn: pick a tile and place it on their mini golf design. After placing around 40 tiles, their mini golf course is complete and players can score them to declare the winner.
Example of a complete mini golf course that a player can create during the game
Minigolf Designer delivers a quite new player experience to board game lovers, mostly due to its free form aspect. The fact that you can create any design gives this feeling of freedom. You can actually play just by following your artistic creativity!
But it's not a purely artistic random placement of pieces either. The puzzle aspect comes from the challenge to assemble the tiles in a way that satisfies a bunch of preferences. However, there is no unique solution; with the 256 tiles present in the box, you can build millions of miniature golf courses!
Competitive players will also enjoy the game by trying to satisfy as much design constraints as they can, if not all (which is possible). There are 7 design aspects that could give you victory points, but none of them are mandatory. Therefore, both kids, casual players and competitive players can enjoy the game but in different ways.
"I personally like to play minigolf, and I always enjoy to discover the various obstacles every time I try a new minigolf. This was the triggering idea for this game. I thought the guys who design real miniature golf courses may have a lot of fun just to invent new obstacles and try to fit all the holes on the available space, in a logical manner. So I designed my game around this idea, and now we can all experience the same fun." - Alban Nanty (designer of this game)
Since this is our first publication, we do not have a network of retailers to get Minigolf Designer to a wider audience, which means this may be your best chance to get the game!
Please note that the final appearance of the game components may differ from the images above.
The mini golf tiles are 4 cm (1.6 inches) wide. The cards are in poker format (around 6 x 9 cm i.e. 3.54 x 2.36 inches). The game box will be 29.7 x 29.7 x 9 cm (11.7 x 11.7 x 3.54 inches). The estimated weight of the box is 2.150 Kg (4.7 pounds) (with complete punch boards).
Here is a video where Alban presents the game components (in their prototype version) while explaining the rules:
As you can see the turn is very fast. Players will need between 36 to 40 tiles to complete their design, which means the players will play around 40 turns before the end of the game.
The tiles are presented to the players on a ruler (with one more tile than the number of players), but they are sorted according to their number printed on the back. When a player pick a tile, she leaves her pawn at the same place. The order of the pawns on the ruler becomes the next turn order.
Therefore, the more victory points the tile you pick has, the more likely you will play last in the next turn, leaving you with less choice in the next turn. On the contrary, if you pick a boring tile, or even if you pass in front of everyone, you will be the first player to choose a tile in the next turn.
Family Version
The above explanation is the basic mode, suitable for kids, family and casual players. This is probably the version you will play for the first time, to get familiarized with the game.
Advanced Version
The game also comes with extra wooden disks and cards, to play a more competitive version of the game. In this version, the players follow the exact same rules as the family version, but at the beginning of the game (and later during the game), players will have a chance to bet secretly on which aspect of their mini golf design they will more focus on. At the end of the game, the players can gain extra victory points, if they are actually better than the other players for the aspect(s) that they chose. However, this is risky, because if they are not the best, they will lose points.
Solo mode
The rule book contains also some rule adaptations to play solo. In solo mode, the player don't need the Rulers, but still draw 2 tiles during each turn, for choosing one. They can pass, meaning not choosing one of the two tiles, but that makes them lose victory points.

Unlike many other board games whose illustration is made on computer, Minigolf Designer is really a game of art. Its original artwork was all paint by hand by our artist Gul. She painted 170 different tiles in 10 x 10 cm (3.9 x 3.9 inches) format, even if we knew that tiles will be smaller in the game (4 x 4 cm or 1.6 x 1.6 inches).
Example of the tiles painted by the artist
We decided to give away those pieces of art, already framed in a modern and sober frame. If you pledge at the "The Game + One Original Art Work" level, you will receive a unique painting already framed and ready to be displayed on your desk. The pieces of art will be randomly distributed to the backers of that pledge level, therefore it will be a surprise to see which tile you received. You can then try to find the tile in the game and maybe even notice some difference if the tile has been edited after scanning.
As we only have 170 painted tiles, we had to limit the quantity for this pledge level, so hurry up if you want your original art work!
An example of an original painted art work in its frame
The above picture is one of the possible tile that you may receive, but each available painting that we give away is different, so the image above is just here to give you an overview of the overall look. The tile that you will get will certainly be different. The frame itself should be the one displayed on the image.
The painting size is around 10 x 10 cm (3.9 x 3.9 inches), and the outside frame is a bit less than 15 x 15 cm (5.9 x 5.9 inches).

For the Land cards Stretch Goal, we thought that it could be a great opportunity to let you leave your little imprint in the game. Even if the stretch goal is reached, you can still participate until the end of the campaign.
Firstly, let me show you all the Land cards already designed and ready for the game:
All the land cards currently designed in the game
Now, if you are interested, you can propose your own land cards!
Here are the few constraints that you should follow:
You don't need to be an artist for your proposal, basically you just have to draw the grid
The land card should contain one, and only one quarter circle tile (whose side equals two tiles)
The number of squares/tiles should be between 34 to 38 (excluding river and lake tiles)
You don't need to assign victory points to your cards, we will do it according to the difficulty of the cards, and we will balance it with the other cards
If you decide to add a river, you should make at least two bridges in order for the player to be able to satisfy the circuit constraint
And here are the rules for the participation:
The participation is only opened to backer (at minimum "The Game" level).
You need to submit your proposal in the form of an image. Post a comment to the project with the link to your image to do your submission.
No more than 3 submissions per backer.
We may ask you to adjust your submission, or decide to not use it, if the card has some gameplay issues, such as if the layout doesn't fit well on the cards, doesn't allow the player to complete his minigolf course, break the game in any way, etc...
By submitting a proposition you automatically authorize Thematic Games to use your proposal to be included and printed in the game.
If we have too many submissions, at the end of the campaign we will choose the one we prefer.
You can propose land cards until the end of the campaign. Once the campaign is finished, no more submission will be accepted.
If there's not enough submission at the end of the campaign, we will create the land cards ourselves. We don't know yet how many land cards we will add for this Stretch Goal, lets see the number of submission that we get first.
Here are the suggestions we got so far:
We run this Kickstarter campaign through our company named Thematic Games. Alban has started up this company in 2015 for the purpose of creating immersive games and entertaining experiences. We believe immersion and story telling is what makes people dream, therefore we always pay attention to the theme of each game we create.
For this project we are also helped by Jerome Levy, an Executive Producer in one of the major Video Game companies, who helps us as an adviser for the Kickstarter campaign and the overall aspect of the project.
For more info on Gul's creative work, you can visit the Wenlin Studio website.

We have friendly shipping for Europe (for the listed countries above), USA, Canada, Australia and China. For many other countries, the price of the game is lower than the limit to pay custom fee, so in such case your parcel will be free of additional cost.
All shipping cost are paid up-front on Kickstarter.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This project is a relaunch of our previous Kickstarter campaign which achieved 67%. We have learned a lot during our first attempt, and we have fixed all the issues that we have discovered during our first launch.

Design
The Design is completed, we have play tested the game many times, and not only with our families and friends, but also with strangers. We found those stranger testers in bars where board game fans meet each week to play. We are confident that the rules are solids, works well and don't need any more tuning.

Artwork
All artwork has been 100% completed.

Editing
100% of the game components has been edited and prepared for production.

Manufacturing
We have found our manufacturer and get a quotation from him. We got some printing sample and pawn sample and are satisfied with the quality.

Shipping
We have contacted various fulfillment companies in order to propose you a friendly shipping. However, due to the current corona virus pandemic, the shipping and fulfillment companies may expect some trouble or delay in certain countries.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Long-lasting design
The game is designed to be played many times thanks to its high replayability value (due to the Client cards that change the game flavor every time it is played).
Reusability and recyclability
Game tokens can be reused in other board games. The cardboard used by the game can be recycled like any paper or cardboard, to recreate recycled papers.
Sustainable materials
The game uses mainly cardboard and wood tokens which is biodegradable.
Sustainable Distribution
We will use fulfillment companies located in major area. The games will be shipped in batches to these companies, who will then redistribute them to the backers.

campaign.story:
In the new Sickest Witch solo story mode, you take on an apprentice who is not only in need to training, but is also looking for revenge. Together, you will hunt town guards and warriors, collecting their body parts, and imbuing them with power. 
"Creates wonderful moments..." and "I think you're going to like it a lot." Great Undead Viking Review here.
Sickest Witch plays similar to role-playing games -- you roll a twenty-sided die to beat your enemy's armor class. The hook is, your powers come from your victims. When you eliminate an enemy, flip their card over to see what body part you have harvested from them. In competitive mode, each body part is also a victory point. In solo mode, you'll need them to survive. The body parts will also dictate the story's end.
Make it personal: you have the option to name your apprentice using the printed PDF. Prompts in the game also give you the option to "roll in" a real life friend into the game experience. As we're all likely shut in and away from our gaming communities, this is a fun way to include a friend in your solo story.  

In this new story mode, you will also draft powerful cards from "the Invert". You play as Emily of Black Branch -- a powerful young witch who has learned how to manipulate portals of influence and ingenuity. 
The print+play enemy board that comes with the new solo story mode has hit point columns. This frees up the D4s for gameplay. It also looks cool. 
Core Game
CORE GAME: is solo and competitive - Includeds 69 cards, 6 custom D4s, 1D20, and a black drawstring bag.
EXPANSION (Sickest Wizard): - Includeds 65 cards, 6 custom D4s, 1D20, and a black drawstring bag. Bottom of the box becomes an interactive "Invert".
Print+Play - Includes both Sickest Witch and Sickest Wizard as well as the new expanded solo story mode. 
Learn to play the competitive mode below in this review by the Undead Viking. Or learn to play here. The game is easy to learn and we have refined the rules using player feedback. A new version of the rules will be included in the print+play PDF.
Expansion - only 400 copies made
That one huge pledge:
UNREAL LOOT CRATE: Beneath the Inverted Church limited edition box set (1 of 100) with all books signed - original Beneath hardcover, full campaign softcover, and Pleasures and Pestilence softcover with Hannah and Emily minis, game pieces, exclusive pin, black bag, and two stickers. A set of Sickest Witch prototype cards and dice (sick-rare) with a certificate of authenticity.
2 physical boxed copies of Sickest Witch with 69 cards, 6 customs D4s, 1D20, and a black draw string bag. You get 2 rare copy of Sickest Wizards. This includes 2 glow-in-the-dark D20s for Sickest Witch and Wizard. You get the original hardcover copy of Beneath, the Inverted Church (1 of 200) signed plus all the Severed Books PDFs: party backstory Generator, Mega Dungeons Maker, Sealed Inside, Beneath (600 page campaign), and the Campaign Notebook.
You get 2 original witch skull drawings by Justin Sirois. You also get a PDF containing all the original Sickest Witch cards + the new solo story mode with player mats, enemy mat, and new content. + All of our dice sets and stickers as well as a hydro stone dice tray which we don't make anymore.
Credits: 
Awesome Video Music by Patrick Lieberkind.

campaign.story:
Update  - April 6:
Due to the success of the campaign, the limited edition version of the deck has very low availability, so we are making the standard edition deck available as a reward and as an add-on. 
The standard edition will have the same cards inside but black ink on the tuck case and the seals will not be individually numbered.  You can add-on a standard edition deck to any pledge for $9 (includes shipping.) Limited edition decks are no longer available for add-on, but once we have an accurate account you still may be able to add-on one prior to fulfillment.
All the rewards with standard decks will have "standard" in the reward title. If it does not, the limited edition deck(s) will be included in that reward selection.
Standard Edition of the Deck
***
Introducing a precisely digitally hand-recreated reproduction of the first published complete transformation playing card deck in the world! The blue "Joan of Arc" deck is the first in a series of six famous decks we plan to release in 2020...  
The very first transformation deck issued by Cotta is from 1805. This deck is probably the most famous of all six, and is incredibly scarce. Original illustrations were fiddling artworks done by hand, on copper plates that were manually engraved with stipple and etching, and the cards were printed on linen period stock that was 97 mm x 69 mm in size, with blank card backs and squared corners at that time. Only the court cards were hand-colored, while the number cards used red stencils.
Cotta’s transformation cards were very successful and became a role model for later transformation decks from other publishers. And since the card backs were blank, individual cards were sometimes used by the nobility as visit cards and for leaving messages, so these playing cards often became multi-purpose items.
There are many historical values in the series of decks! But if you are only interested in the deck details & images instead of history & backstory, then please skip about half way down.
 The story behind these playing cards, which probably conceal the most of the world's playing card secrets, begins in Tübingen, a city in southwest Germany.
The atmosphere here is bursting with memories and experiences of the past. Visitors today can still enjoy the small stairs, narrow alleys, and pointed gables that shape the silhouette of old Tübingen on the way to its famous castle. Tübingen is home to one of Europe’s oldest universities and even today combines the colorful bustle of an university town full of students with the flair of a restored medieval center and a touch of many ancient cultures. The Romans already left some traces of their presence here in AD 85, but the city itself dates from the 6th or 7th century. Little wonder that this city attracted many eminent notables and artists, who found it inspirational for their work. 
 The idea behind the concept of Cotta's transformation decks was to create a series of six decks on an annual basis from 1805-1811. Each deck would focus on a different theme, with the first set based on Schiller's play Jeanne d'Arc, which was about the famous historical figure Joan of Arc. 
Forming a "Card Almanac" (Karten Almanach), each card in the deck would represent one of the 52 weeks in a calendar year. At the time it was popular to print various almanacs, which were special pocket books for the new year, and often included a short poem or quote for each week of the calendar year. It was a logical move to connect each of these 52 weeks with a playing cards.
Johann Friedrich Cotta (*April 27, 1764 - December 29, 1832), publisher, industrial pioneer, and politician, the man at the helm of family publishing house J. G. Cotta (founded yet in late 17th century by his grandfather Johann Georg Cotta *1631 - 1692) from Tübingen, Germany, around 1804 went on to produce a series of six playing card almanacs in successive years from 1805-1811, with a new deck appearing in all but one of those years. 
In addition to Johann Friedrich Cotta's high standing as a publisher, he was a man of great practical energy, which flowed into various fields of activity, he promoted even many reforms and supported talented individuals. It is also noticeable that in such period of his life he published numerous works of his own literature, political materials, and also yearbooks.
Cotta did have the goal of replacing the "inelegant" designs of contemporary German playing cards with a more artistic high-quality deck. But these playing cards were not intended for playing games with in the first place, but rather for stimulating discussion about the "themed" images on each of the cards. Each year the court cards were designed to represent another theme, while the number cards featured pictures that were largely independent drawings without a common topic, since they were especially intended as conversation pieces and depicted happenings.
The Cotta's famous house was the place, where among other brilliant German authors of the time, the works of Schiller and later of Goethe were published there in its journal pages, as well as journal's major contributor was Heinrich Heine, who with his early lyric poetry has inspired even composers such as Robert Schumann and Franz Schubert who set his works into music... 
So the picture that emerges from this time in Cotta's life is that he was constantly engaged in thoughtful conversation with literary men, and enjoyed close friendships with leading figures of the day like Schiller, Huber, Gottlieb Konrad Pfeffel, and others, many of whose works he published.
Johann Friedrich Cotta's long term friendship with the famous German poet, dramatist, philosopher, and historian Friedrich Schiller was well known. In 1795 Schiller and Cotta founded the Horen, a periodical that became important for students of German literature. Schiller's goal was to use his work to infuse higher ideas into the common lives of men, by giving them a nobler human culture, and “to reunite the divided political world under the banner of truth and beauty.” It was as a result of this relationship that Goethe became part of a close circle of friends with Cotta and Schiller. Even today there is evidence at Cotta's house of Goethe having slept there. 
It is probably this friendship that gave birth to the idea of creating a unique decks of transformation playing cards with the purposes of igniting discussion about the "themed" picture on each card. This was after all a time when people were open to such ideas, and producing a series of playing cards as almanacs for a continuous period of years was a natural development.
With help from you the backers we plan to produce the entire 6 deck series! The color of each tuck box created by Azured Ox has been inspired by Goethe's experimental optic and color theory, since Goethe was an important contemporary of Cotta, along with Schiller. (Goethe's deepest immersion into colors was during Cotta's decks issuing.)
Limited Edition Decks
Standard Edition Decks
Goethe’s spent years on his theory (built on wavelength theory of light broken into 7 colors demonstration after Newton), which became a personal obsession in his last years, and which he considered more important than his literary works.
Goethe believed that colors arise from the interaction between light and darkness, light and dark edges along the spectrum; that colors are realities, phenomena of nature... His color theory was intended to be a paradigmatic model for natural science in general, and Goethe was concerned with the psychological effects of each color, as well.
He believed that colors symbolize different values and that colors have a clear effect on the mind and feelings. Goethe had little use for concepts of divinity or for systematic thinking. His theory formulated a psychological and philosophical account of the way we actually experience color as a phenomenon.
Much of historical happenings, influences and activities would later find a place in the Cotta decks, including events in the life of Cotta's own family and of notable figures like Schiller and Goethe. Other important influences include the literature, art, history, politics (e.g. Napoleon's invasion), and religious reforms of the time, which all served as an important context to shape the art in the decks themselves. 
For example, Schiller experienced a grave illness that led to his death, and this around as well as many more is even depicted in the playing cards from the Cotta decks. In short, there is significant evidence of such connections between the artistic pictures and the immediate context that produced them.
It is especially significant for the way it displays meaningful and inspirational happenings from the time; in this first deck, such as Schiller on his death-bed (Six of Clubs) or sadness of Goethe (probably depicted on Nine of Clubs), assumed depictions from life of noble families, etc...
 First almanac deck: Jeanne d'Arc (Year 1805) 
The images on the court cards are characters inspired by Schiller's play "Die Jungfrau von Orleans" ("Joan of Arc"). 
The central figure of Joan of Arc is depicted as the Queen of Spades, the Maid of Orleans who inspired the French army to victory, but was later burned at the stake.
Features:
Printed by USPCC on Classic Stock
Poker Size
Embossed Finish
52 Cards + 2 Extra Jokers + 2 Extra Collectible Cards
Metallic Ink On Box & Backs
Custom Numbered Seals
Puzzle Image on all Tuck Spines of the Series
Digitally Hand-Recreated and Designed by Azured Ox
 Produced By Will Roya 
Cotta's first deck was designed by Countess Mary Day von Jennison-Walworth (sometimes spelled with a single `n'). Her maiden name was Beauclerk, and she was the wife of Count Francis Jenison Walworth (1764–1824). She was an illegitimate (twin) child who led a very colorful life, and finally settled down somewhat after marrying Count Francis in 1797. (Probably, she was creating illustrations in Stuttgart.)
We are limiting this 1st deck to only 1,000 copies with numbered seals. We may print a small amount additional decks without seals to meet demand or for a special edition. 
The entire 6 deck series is in many ways designed by Azured Ox to meet collector's demand (as "collection of historical books") and will be produced with the piece of puzzle image on each tuck spine (left side of box) to create together nice display of the Tuebingen monument surroundings, where the idea for Cotta's decks was born. 
The publisher's name was placed on the Ace of Clubs as follows: "A Tubinge chez J. G. Cotta, Libraire."
The transformations on the number cards have no reference to each other or to the court cards (as well lots of them might be considered as unexplained mystery).
The court cards were designated with the words "Valet", "Dame", and "Roi", which are the French terms corresponding to the Jack, Queen, and King.
In the first deck, beside Joan of Arc depicted as the Queen of Spades, other individuals closely associated with Joan include Etienne de Vignolles or La Hire (Jack of Hearts), who helped Joan to victory in the battle of Patay in 1429; and Raymond (Jack of Diamonds), a peasant who was Joan's page.
Key political leaders who figured prominently in the events surrounding Joan's life are also represented, including King Charles VII (King of Hearts), the French monarch who relied on Joan's help to reach the Rhiems, the traditional place of coronation; Charles' mother Isabeau (Queen of Hearts), who was in league with Charles' enemy; Charles' mistress Agnes Sorel (Queen of Diamonds); Charles' opponent Philippe the Good (King of Diamonds), an ally of England; and the king of Naples, René d'Anjou (King of Clubs), who lost the kingdom after defeat in battle. General Talbot (King of Spades) was the English commander of the outpost of Orleans at Saint Loup, who was wounded in battle, captured, and was part of a prisoner exchange.
Both Joan's "sister" Louison (Queen of Clubs) and Montgomery (Jack of Clubs) are fictional creations of Schiller, while the fictional Lionel (Jack of Spades) is the character who holds up Joan's sword in a location revealed by the voices that she supposedly heard telling her to help.
 Clubs: Montgomery, Louison (Joan's fictional sister), René d'Anjou (King of Sicily) 
Diamonds: Raimond (villager), Agnes Sorel (Charles' mistress), Philippe de Bourgogne 
Hearts: Etienne de Vignolles (La Hire), Isabeau de Baviere (Charles' mother), Charles VII (King of France) 
Spades: Lionel (knight), Joan of Arc, Talbot
At last we came with an idea to reflect opposite of noble life and to bring closer to you even more of the unique artistic history placed on extra collectible playing cards...
Also we thought it could be interesting to put another illustrations from the far past on the additional extra cards, in respect to year almanacs, we came with an idea of twelve calendar months in the series as exclusive collection of unique historical artworks...
An absolutely original playing card masterpiece to hang on your wall (double sided)
 New Standard Deck Rewards
 Please note: Limited edition decks are no longer available for add-on. After the campaign, when I have a more accurate count, some may be available to add-on prior to fulfillment.
 The end of funding period for this first "blue" deck of the series is symbolically set to:
 Johann Friedrich Cotta's 
 (256th) Birthday on April 27, 2020 
As of the launch of this campaign we have already submitted art to USPCC to prepare for print.  USPCC recently reported a 10 day shut down because of the COVID-19 outbreak but we are confident we can deliver this project by the end of July if they are not shut down for more then 30 days. If we do have a delay it will be  communicated with backers in a speedy and transparent manner.
 We have already put a significant amount of resources in making this deck possible. But if we can pass 20k in funding we will include something special for every backer or upgrade the deck in some way.

campaign.story:
Digital mockup.
Do you already own my other fantasy RPG supplements that were created thanks to the support of Kickstarter backers? Then you're looking for either the $1 (PDF) or $18 (print, U.S. only) reward levels. All of the other listed rewards are for those gamemasters who missed out on my earlier projects.
Digital mockup.
While working on writing the remaining PDFs to fulfill the A Dozen Troubling Rumors Kickstarter campaign (see the project page), I ran into a mental wall and spent a weekend staring at a blank page. No matter how hard I tried, my brain was locked and I found myself unable to write. The stresses of today's challenges had, obviously, dug deep into my mind and was blocking my ability to create.
Sample page spread.
Whenever I have found myself suffering from writer's block before, I have discovered that shifting gears and working on something new is often the best way to get the creative muscles running again. So that is what I did, adjusting my focus to a collection of city sites that I thought would be both fun to create and a valuable addition to every gamemaster's toolkit.
Sample page spread, city sites.
Within a matter of hours, the outline for Fantasy City Sites and Scenes was locked down, and my fingers were jamming at the keyboard, quickly creating characters, places, and situations that were each designed to drop into a fantasy campaign. At times, I stitched together links between the newly-formed places and characters, doing all that I could to make the book a package that would instantly inspire gamemasters and add depth to any fantasy city.
Sample page spread, city sites.
City sites. Each of the sixteen locations detailed in the book is presented on a two-page spread (for a total of 32 pages worth of locations) and includes a few assorted details the gamemaster can use to add flavor to the site, as well as assorted other bits of info that vary from location to location to give the site a little personality. Hooks that may lead to adventure are sprinkled throughout this section of the book.
Sample page spread, city scenes.
City scenes. In addition to the city sites, the book also includes twelve pages of encounter ideas. Divided into two sections -- daytime scenes and nighttime scenes -- this section of the book is for those gamemasters who are looking to throw challenges at the party as they walk the city streets.
Digital mockup.
So that we don't accidentally cause project delays, there will be no stretch goals for this campaign. I'd much rather deliver on schedule than risk running late with delivery of the rewards.
I know that the lack of stretch goals will cause some of you to turn away, but I ask that you keep this in mind: The 52-page PDF reward is only a buck, making this a great deal for any gamemaster who enjoys running city encounters and adventures.
For those who missed out on the Dungeon Challenge Cards (details here), I am making those cards available as a part of this project. The Dungeon Challenge Cards final product is a 36-card deck, packed inside a custom tuck box. I am down to the last of the decks and currently do not have plans to reprint these cards. Maybe in the future, but not soon. 
The Book of Unusual Potions is a 64-page saddle-stitched work that is 5.5" (wide) by 8.5" (tall) in size and includes potions, potion ingredients, and more. Presented in a systemless format, this book is for use with many fantasy roleplaying games and is as colorful in appearance as it is in the descriptions of the many potions described inside.
Please see the Kickstarter page for more information.
Also available in PDF at DrivethruRPG.
Over the last few years, I have created four different decks of Outdoor Encounter Cards. Each deck includes 36 cards, and all of them share a common back so that gamemasters may shuffle the different decks together. For more information on this series, please see the individual Kickstarter campaigns:
Outdoor Encounter Cards
Outdoor Encounter Cards 2
Outdoor Encounter Cards 3
Outdoor Encounter Cards 4
Did you miss out on the Kickstarter campaign for A Dozen Sinister Rumors? Now's your chance to grab these 17 different PDFs and expand you collection of GM tools! 
If you wish to buy single PDFs, and not all 17 of these titles, you can find each one at DrivethruRPG.
Delayed Blast Gamemaster is a systemless fantasy RPG zine for use with most games. This gamemaster-targeted resource is packed with monsters, adventure hooks, and all sorts of random stuff. Please see the individual Kickstarter campaigns (issue one, issue two, and issue three) for sample pages and to learn more about the zine.
You can find the zine in PDF today at DrivethruRPG.com.

Digital mockup.
***
Most artwork used under license from Shutterstock.com, created by Alex Mit, Algol, camilkuo, IR Stone, Julia Tochilina, Konstantin G, Patrik Ruzic, PON-PON, Twisted Die Productions, and Warpaint. Additional artwork by Enmanuel “Lema” Martinez, used under license.
Music audio is Bernard FINAL by Ian Alex Mac, available at the Free Music Archive.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
After years of experience with Kickstarter, running and backing projects, combined with decades of experience in publishing, I think _most_ of the largest challenges and risks have been avoided. The book is complete, and all that remains is funding and the project review stage where project supporters are encouraged to crowdsource spotting and correcting the typos that are surely somewhere inside the work.

However, things can go wrong. As an individual, I do not have access to a company to assist with packing and shipping rewards (a friend helps!), and I have no control over life. Everything should ship on schedule, but things can (and sometimes do) go wrong. If something goes off the rails, I will post an update to explain the situation.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
I love the end of the night. When someone is about to go home, and I say "How about a game of X before you leave?" They smile and sit down. They can't resist because they know:
The game is fast (like 10 minutes to play)
It's quick to teach (like get started in 30 seconds)
There will be tension and exciting moments
It ends the night on a satisfying note of getting in one more quality game
This game series exists because I want there to be more games like that. We've focused on easy to teach before, but these are SUPER easy to teach.
But there is enough strategy that after the game your mind will wander back to a couple of key turns, and you'll wonder if you should have played just a little bit differently.
And they have those turns...
That turn in GPS where the spinner lands on the spot that helps you but not your opponents. 
That turn in Sequoia where you have to decide if it is worth fighting for the best spot or better to grab multiple spots where there is less competition. 
That turn in Mountain Goats when you bump the leader off the mountain right before they win. 
And Holy Toledo, these games are just $15 each. 
These games were designed for adult gamers, but they are playable with the whole family, including kids as young as 5 with some coaching.  They're also great options when your non-gamer friends ask to play a game, and you want something that you can teach and start playing quickly.
In Mountain Goats you work to move your goats to the top of 6 different mountains where they can score points as long as they stay there. You can share spaces with other goats on the way up, but there is only room for one goat at the top of each mountain. If someone else's goat moves to the mountain top, they will kick you off and you'll have to start your trek over.
It's a game about timing. You need to not just get to the top of the mountain, but get there when no one else is in position to knock you off.
It's a game about keeping your eye on your opponents. Maximizing your score, but also making sure you don't let anyone else score too much.
There is the fun chance to knock each other off the mountain. But it doesn't feel too mean because you can only knock back goats that are in a scoring position, and it isn't a huge setback. It is just a normal part of the cycle of the game.
Read a draft version of the full rulebook for Mountain Goats. 


In Sequoia you are trying to grow the tallest trees in 11 different forests. After your 10 turns, if you have the tallest tree, then you get the victory points from that forest. Second place gets a small consolation prize.
Each turn, you get to grow two of your trees. Which trees you choose will determine if you win or lose. Do you keep fighting in a forest with competition, or start growing your tree somewhere else? You'll have to wrestle with the dice to grow the tree you want.
Sequoia is a game of choosing your battles.
The dice will always give you choices, but they will be hard choices.
Ties in each forest are decided by extra tie-breaker rounds that can lead to epic finishes.
Read a draft version of the full rulebook for Sequoia.

You're launching GPS satellites into space. They need to orbit the earth in the correct order. But your launch windows are limited. You can only launch satellites where the spinner points each turn. It is your job to pick the best satellite for each launch to get your birds in order before your opponents.
GPS is a game about how fun it is to spin that spinner. And it is a very satisfying spin.
It is a game about rooting for the rocket to land on your number.
GPS is a game about putting yourself in a position where the spinner is most likely to help you.
 Read a draft version of the full rulebook for GPS.
You won't be paying for any extra air in your boxes. The games set up big, but they store small. There will always be room to shove one of these into your game bag.
It is a little bit shorter and a little bit wider than a box that holds two decks of cards side by side. It is also about twice as thick so the lid will stay in place much better.
1. For the purpose of shipping, the 3 small games pack (GPS + Sequoia + Mountain Goats) will count as just one game.
2. DO NOT manually increase your pledge amount to cover the shipping cost. It will make both our lives much more complicated when it is time to complete the pledge manager.
3. If you want to pledge for additional games we publish, just manually increase the amount you are pledging. $15 for GPS, Mountain Goats, or Sequoia. $39 for the small games three pack. $34 for On Tour Europe and USA, QE, Bites, or Loot of Lima.
4. Shipping prices will be the same during the pledge manager and you will be able to add more games then at the "additional game" shipping price.  
5. The price of GPS, Mountain Goats, and Sequoia will probably be higher in the pledge manager. We want to offer Kickstarter backers the best possible price.
6. Instead of offering a discount for buying a full case of games, we have steeply discounted the shipping rates for buying additional games. This way you can order the exact number of games your group needs.
7. This campaign is Canadian, EU, UK, and USA, and Australian friendly.
8. There are two main reasons the Canadian and European shipping costs more than US shipping. Since we ship fewer games to these fulfillment centers, it costs us more per game to get them there. And, we have to pay taxes when we bring the games into these regions so that you don't have to pay any taxes when they are delivered to you.
Email help@boardgametables.com if you want to carry one of these games in your Friendly Local Game Store, if you want to offer them through distribution, or if you would like to localize them for your country.
Chad is the owner of BoardGameTables.com and the designer of Sequoia.  Here are some games he loves that aren't getting talked about enough: Blockers, Capital Lux, Factory Funner, The King is Dead, Nations, Greed, Prospectus, Haggis, and Startups.
Katy has to answer all your support emails and messages. So please be nice to her. With a wide range of gaming tastes she can be found playing Lisboa one night and a Harry Potter RPG the next. But it gets a little weird when she role-plays as a wizard during the game of Lisboa.
Anca is the co-artist and graphic designer for On Tour, QE, Bites, and Loot of Lima. She has a poster featured in the Board Game Geek Artist series. Her husband and baby girl are always involved in the projects, from mandatory play testing and prototyping, to artistic suggestions. 
Daniel Profiri is the co-artist for this series. Whenever he's not illustrating board games, he's drawing photorealistic portraits and working on interior design projects. 
Stefan Risthaus is the designer of Mountain Goats. He lives in Northern Germany and likes playing and developing games with history as a theme, but also quick fillers and family games. His wife also designs games and is the first and most important play testing person for his games.
Hartmut Kommerell is the designer of GPS. He has forgotten a lot of the math theory he once studied, but still uses the skills to design games and to puzzle around at work. With a 6-headed family, he can always test games with players of any age.
Estimated delivery January 2021. Our normal math would project a November delivery. We added a couple of extra months because there is a lot of uncertainty right now, and shipping in November/December can add extra delays as everyone else is trying to get stuff in by Christmas.
As with all our Kickstarters, we will fully refund your pledge at any time before we ship the game to you. For any reason. No limits. No restrictions.
Right now some people have some understandable concerns about the health of the economy and small businesses. It is our policy and will continue to be our policy to always keep enough cash on hand to fulfill (produce and ship) all outstanding Kickstarter commitments and preorders.
This is a short campaign, so don't delay.

The game will be manufactured by Panda Game Manufacturing. They are the industry leader. We have printed several games with them before. No one is more qualified to make these games and we have already been working with them for months to make sure it goes smoothly. They did have some delays earlier in the year. They handled them safely and superbly and are now operating at 100% capacity again.

campaign.story:
Welcome to the latest Kickstarter campaign for The Fantasy Trip (official website)! TFT is Steve Jackson's classic fantasy roleplaying game, revived thanks to the support of Kickstarter backers! Now, with your support, we will add two more books to the growing library of titles for The Fantasy Trip and open up new doors for gamemasters and solo adventurers! 
Read on to learn more about the two new books -- The Book of Unlife and Red Crypt -- and then select a reward level (detailed at right) to join the project.
To start playing The Fantasy Trip right now, please download the free Melee PDF from our online store: Warehouse 23. These rules will give you a taste of the much larger, deeper system that is found In the Labyrinth.
They are neither alive nor dead. They inhabit the world in between. But all too often the living are their prey.
The Book of Unlife includes 44 creatures for The Fantasy Trip (visit the official website), a guide to the general powers and vulnerabilities of the unliving, and a complete adventure setting, The Haunting of Holner House.
Unlife is a broad term covering a wide variety of entities which are not “living beings” in the traditional sense of the word. They may have once been alive, like Ghosts. They may be true “undead,” like Nosferatu. They may be animated forms, like Zombies and Golems. They may be entities of pure spiritual energy, like Poltergeists, or immortal beings from the unearthly realms, like Banshees. Whatever they are, they are not alive in the way life is usually understood.
The first part of this book, The Types of Unlife, is a guide to many of the known kinds of unlife. The second part, The Characteristics of Unlife, covers the unusual abilities that unlife beings may have, as well as techniques that can be used against hostile unlife creatures. The third part is an adventure setting that will bring the party up against several formidable unliving foes, as well as some living ones!
The Book of Unlife is a 64-page 8.5" x 11" book, written by Howard Kistler.
You study the face on the wanted poster. 30-ish, with ash-blond hair and a hook-shaped scar under his right eye. Jack Smoke.
Smoke is a Redcap, part of a secret society plotting to overthrow the established order of wizards, priests, and guilds. Like many Redcaps, Smoke trusts gadgets or potions over magic. You heard he was once a priest who earned his nickname burning heretics. Then Smoke discovered his cult’s “miracles” were mere spells cast to delude the congregation. He lost his faith and turned against all wizardry as well, embracing the Redcap cause. What he didn’t lose was his fanaticism.
Recently, Smoke detonated a gas bomb at a town fair. It poisoned the wizard he targeted – and several children.
“Unfortunate collateral damage,” said the Redcap communiqué that claimed credit for the assassination.
You intend to bring Jack Smoke to justice . . . and claim the 1,000 silvers the baron offers for his head!
Red Crypt is a programmed adventure for a single character. It is designed for The Fantasy Trip: In The Labyrinth (available in both hardcover and print-on-demand softcover). If you instead have both Melee and Wizard, you can still play, with a few simplifications.
This adventure establishes locations, gives you decisions to make, and tells you the outcomes of those decisions. You will need six-sided dice, a straightedge, and scratch paper, along with counters and megahex tiles.
Since Red Crypt uses only one player character, it can be played two ways:
 Solitaire: One lone player creates or selects an existing adventurer character. That character may acquire friends during the adventure, creating a party, but they are all run by the same person. When combat occurs, the book gives instructions regarding the foes in each location; the player sets up figures on a tactical map and plays out the battles, running both sides.
 Two-Player: One player creates a character (or uses an existing one) and plays through the scenario. When foes are encountered, the other player controls them and tries to defeat the adventurer. The second player can also act as Game Master (GM); they read the paragraphs and resolve rules disputes or actions not covered by these instructions.
Red Crypt is a 24-page 8.5" x 11" book, written by David Pulver.
Please keep in mind that selecting add-ons will impact your total shipping costs. See the FAQ for more information.

International Note:  If you are outside of the United States and wish to order direct from Steve Jackson Games, please see our online store: www.warehouse23.com.
NO REWARD NOTE: You must select a reward level to choose add-ons. As a policy, we do not make add-ons available to the No Reward pledges; in our experience, that leads to challenges and difficulties that cause troubles for all involved.
NOTE: Street addresses only.
After the Kickstarter project closes, and after all pledges are collected, we will open the BackerKit pledge manager. There, you will tell us your Warehouse 23 email address, provide your physical address, and pay for shipping (if you are receiving physical rewards). See the FAQ for estimated shipping costs.
Failure to complete your BackerKit survey by the deadline (which will be announced in a Kickstarter update once the pledge manager opens) will result in a refund and removal from the project. We cannot allow projects to remain open forever; we must set firm deadlines so that we can properly close campaigns.
If you wish, you may choose to use a fulfillment service. This allows you to pledge for the project and then provide us with a U.S. address for delivery of your rewards. Forwarding from the fulfillment service, as well as any local fees, is your responsibility when using a fulfillment company.
INTERNATIONAL DELIVERY NOTE: There are no physical rewards offer to international backers. If the project closes successfully, we will offer both titles through Amazon's print-on-demand service, which will make it cheaper for you to purchase the print books (shipping will cost a lot less). 
We continue to search for reliable, economical solutions to international Kickstarter delivery.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Challenge 1: Manufacturing/modeling easy to print items
Solution - Experience! I’ve been 3D Printing since 2015 and modeling since 2013. In that time, I’ve learned how to create models that don’t require supports, rafts or high infill. (Honestly, complex creations that require supports are the BANE of 3D printing! Many swarings have happened in this house due to the struggles of printing items that require complex supports.) I have owned 11+ printers (no kidding!) We currently have 3 Prusa MK3’s, a Moai, and a ShuffleXL. 

Challenge 2: Time
Solution - Self-employed! Since the Fates End Dice Tower prototype has already been built (and hundreds have already been printed) I just need the time to create the remaining Dice Towers. I have the software, hardware, skill and experience, all I need is time. I am self-employed so I have complete control over my time! All I have to do is schedule the time in, and boom - we’re on track!
By funding this project, you make it possible for me to focus on this project instead of client work for a time. YOU are my client! Let’s make this happen, together!

We heard your feedback and we went back to the drawing board. Townbuilder Unlimited is what we came up with.
The Townbuilder is a web application with which you can create custom 3D printable buildings for Tabletop Games. We provide detailed 3D models in the form of small building blocks that you can then use to create the perfect building for your table. All of our buildings can be printed support free and feature playable interior.
You can either start from scratch or modify one of our many prepared templates to fit your needs.
PLAY

When you back this campaign, you will get unlimited access to the Townbuilder, meaning you can build, download and print as many buildings as you want... forever. Depending on the reward tier you back at, you will gain access to different themes, which will be available to you in the Townbuilder.

We are working with  2nd Dynasty to bring SciFi into the Townbuilder! These tiles ARE NOT PART OF THE CAMPAIGN PLEDGES and will cost you 15€ as an addon. For a lot more info check our update on this.
We have partnered up with the awesome folk from Arcane Minis who just ran the Skies of Sordane campaign.
Through this collab every backer that gets access to Premium Set II: Steampunk will get Steampunk themed airports added to their pledge for FREE. These will be modular as everything in the Townbuilder, allowing you to go for any width and lenght.
Benny and his team at Arcane Minis will also create interchangeable stands that will allow the ships to dock to our buildings, raising and lowering them to fit with our 50mm height system!
Their Kickstarter special prices and exclusive Arcane Dragon Mini are only available until May 1st, so head on over and show them some love from us!
CHECK OUT THE SKIES OF SORDANE LATE PLEDGES HERE
The usefulness of our tool relies upon a large selection of themes to choose from. There are only so many classical medieval buildings one can print before being fed up.
That is why our main focus for the future is expanding our themes. As a proof of concept that the Townbuilder has potential, we chose very classical themes. These are represented by our "Basic Sets", which are included in every pledge level and also in the free version of the Townbuilder.
The Basic Themes include Stone, Fachwerk, some Miscellaneous Items, and corresponding Medieval Roofs.
Check out our showcases below but note that they do not display all models individually as this would simply take up to much time and work.

Townbuilder Basic
The Basic is free for everyone. As soon as you sign up for a free account after the Kickstarter you can try out the Townbuilder and even testprint some buildings. Obviously we want to encourage buying the Townbuilder, therefore the functionality of the Basic version is... well pretty basic.
Townbuilder Unlimited
The Unlimited Version has everything you need to build hundreds of custom houses. Every functionality we think makes using the Townbuilder easier will be included here.
Townbuilder Infinite
The Infinite Version adds nothing you need... but a lot of things you want. Want a 20 story high wizard tower? If your PC can handle it, knock yourself out. Want to create nice rendered pictures of your building while exploring them in first person perspective, seeing through the eyes of a miniature, here you go!  Want to create a custom sign for each guild of your world, with their custom logo and name... guess what? Townbuilder Infinite is for you.




Apprentice
The "Apprentice Townbuilder" includes the Townbuilder "Unlimited" Edition and all Basic sets. This tier allows you to create an endless number of buildings in the classical medieval fantasy style. Perfect for people that want to get started in the hobby or that just want to test out the tool for a low price.
Journeyman
The "Journeyman Townbuilder" also includes the Townbuilder "Unlimited" Edition but a lot more models. Two additional sets are included here, which will be based on community decision so you can influence what you get. And then all Stretchgoals that will be unlocked are also included here. So if the Kickstarter takes off, you will get a lot of different models for your money, enabling you to build all kinds of different buildings.
Master
The "Master Townbuilder" includes the Townbuilder "Infinite". In this premium Townbuilder Version, you will find loads of cool features that let you enhance your gameplay. These range from a rendering studio that allows you to walk around in and outside your building and take screenshots of it, to a custom logo and text tool, which will allow you to upload your own custom logos and add them to banners and signs inside the Townbuilder. We have a lot of plans for these cool gadgety features and we already started working on some of them as the development of all basic features comes to a close.
Guild Head
The "Smith's guild head" includes everything listed above for the Master Townbuilder and one additional feature: You get to decide two 100% custom models that we will sculpt for you and add to the Townbuilder. This can be anything you want, from a vegetable garden for your farm village to the symbol of your game's largest Kingdom as a banner to be affixed to your buildings. This allows for a whole new level of customization. Just an idea though, choose something that you want to use a lot, something that we don't feature yet and that will be a common feature for your buildings. 
Syndicate Leader
The "Smith's syndicate leader" includes everything listed above for the Master Townbuilder and one teeny tiny additional feature... You are playing a Steampunk game but the community didn't vote for the steampunk stretchgoal? Boy, do I have something for you.
YOU GET TO COMMISSION A SET !!!!
Yes you can trust your eyes, this is an actual tier we offer. We will create a custom set for you and do our best to make it as close to your wishes as possible while still having it fit with our system.





If we reach the 1000€ that are necessary to keep the servers running for the coming years, the real fun begins. If you are unfamiliar with the way stretch goals work, here is a quick introduction: Whenever the campaign's funding reaches a certain threshold a stretch goal is unlocked. If we raise enough money to keep the office running for a full month, we can release an additional set at no cost, that's the basic idea.
Each stretch goal unlocked means you get more bang for your buck and we get to do what we love as a job, win-win!








We have partnered with the awesome folks of OTP Miniatures and Scenery to offer you guys the option to get your buildings printed!
Though we don't offer printed Kickstarter tiers this time around, every backer of the Kickstarter will receive 10% off their first order for a building created in the Townbuilder at OTP's shop. This way you get your print at the same discount as if it was bought during the Kickstarter.
After the Kickstarter we will also offer seller licenses. If you own a print shop or offer a printing service, feel free to reach out to us via info@townsmith.de .




We are a small company from Saarland, Germany. Our team consists of (currently four) tabletop enthusiasts, who love nerdy shit and who enhance tabletop games with 3D printing! Tom, Christopher, and Monika are computer scientists and Leevke is our intermedia designer.
Christopher "Korson" Adam - PM, CEO, 3D Dev, 3D printing Enthusiast, DM
"Greetings! I'm the guy, who brought 3D printing to Townsmith. I've been playing tabletop games, namely Dungeons and Dragons, for just about 4 years now. I found out very early that being the game master was perfect for me and I've GMd ever since.
I soon developed a need for something more than just a piece of paper when designing my encounters. Equipped with a cheap Anet A8, I began to delve deep into 3D printing for tabletop games. From then on, my arsenal of both models and printers started growing until I got frustrated with the limited customization options for the terrain that is out there.
For Townsmith, I take on the role of the project manager, 3D programmer, and CEO. If anything weird happens in the Townbuilder, yeah that's most likely my fault."
Tom "Zatho" Zahlbach, CTO, Webdeveloper - Fullstack, DM, Player, Documentation Enthusiast
"Hey, I'm Tom. I'm the guy that had to read around 300 pages of Amazon Web Services documentation to get this project hosted for all of you. So yeah, I am somewhat of a masochist ... but, I also got to code a bunch which, if anything in this world, I adore. Everything website-related and invisible to you, as well as all the things behind the website, are written mostly by me. Additionally, I also take care of our AWS infrastructure. In my free time, I play D&D 5e with my friends both as a player and as a DM
For Townsmith I take on the role of CTO. Which... well, says not much since I get to help with everything that needs to be worked on."
Monika "Her Smolness" Unruh - Lead 3D Artist, Dice Enthusiast, Player
"Hey I'm Monika, I'm a Scorpio and 1,62 m tall, whatever you want to do with that information. I've known Tom and Christopher since school and started playing DnD with them in 2017, which made me become a dice-hoarder. When the two of them came up with the idea of Townsmith I was really hyped about it. Half-jokingly I asked them if they needed someone to help with the 3D modeling since I'm somewhat of an artistic person and was interested in trying digital art and 3D modeling.
To my surprise, they said yes and so I came on board and am now a 3D modeler for Townsmith, but I'm still learning, so if the models start floating randomly that's probably on me."
Oliver "Ore" Inglen - Master of the positive aura
"Hello, my name is Oliver. I am new to the world of tabletops, dungeons and dragons, but have been working in 3D and modeling for many years. Actually, I was working in the field of architectural modeling and visualizations until a mutual friend brought me to Christopher. Since then I have been working on my sculpturing techniques for modeling your feature blocks and will also do some concept art! I am really happy to be able to support the Townsmith team while doing fun work. If you have any suggestions for details, get in touch with me. Can´t wait to model all this!"
Leevke "Insomnyu" Reher - Concept Artist, Supporting 3D Artist, Meme Enthusiast
"Ahoy! I'm Leev! My full name is Leevke Fee Thordis Reher but that's kinda overkill, so call me Leev. I've been playing lots of Pen&Paper in my early childhood but couldn't seem to find a fitting group when I got older. But in 2018, I was introduced to Christopher and his great dedication to Dungeons and Dragons. Since I'm currently studying InterMedia Design, the opportunity to do my internship at Townsmith presented itself.
I joined shortly before the Kickstarter launched, so until now I did some of the concept art. Later I'll dive into some of the 3D Modeling and digital design for the community voted themes. So if there's anything wrong, blame the others, I'm innocent."
If you have any questions about us or what we do, feel free to join our Discord Server and get in touch with us!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As you can clearly see, we are a very young team.
This is our first project though not our first Kickstarter campaign. A few months ago we already launched a Kickstarter with a different business model. We have learned a lot since then and we also improved the Townbuilder.

Still, we are inexperienced by industry standards (Printable Scenery, Heroforge, Fat Dragon Games, etc.). Though we do our best to be responsive and professional, but our lack of experience will be visible when it comes to some aspects.
Will the site be up 100% of the time? I doubt it.
Will we fix it as soon as it goes down? Yes, we will.
Will the range of themes increase as fast as heroforge's does? Well, it depends. It took us about three months to get the current models going, but we have gotten a lot faster at it and we will have more time to invest into modeling since there will be less programming work to do.

Most importantly: The Townbuilder is basically ready for release weeks before the launch of the Kickstarter and we only need to polish up a few things, including the UX. There is little risk that you will not be able to create and download buildings after the Kickstarter closes.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
IMPORTANT: This campaign is for a set of digital STL files, without physical products
Thank you very much for the interest in the project.

Fantasy miniatures Vol1 is my first Kickstarter, this first volume is formed by a set of 12 characters of the fantasy genre. You will receive the digital files for each one. These models are ideal for resin printers, but also suitable for FDM printers. If this Kickstarter is financed, in the future, probably in the month of March, volume two would be issued, which would be composed of more characters, including warriors and warriors.
These characters can be used in wargame games, or to make your own invented campaigns. The objective is to take out 3 volumes of miniatures set with a total of approximately 30 miniatures, this would be the first delivery.
All the characters have been modeled with the 3D modeling program Zbrush, I have been a digital modeler for 2 years, I had previously made collectible figures, this is my first immersion in the world of miniatures, then you can see some images of the different views of each of the characters:
What will you receive?
Each figure has been exported as a high quality STL file. In addition, they will have two options when printing each character, since the file will include a solid piece and other cut pieces, so you can print the entire character, or print it by pieces, the files are 100% scalable, and that the cut pieces are included makes it possible to print the file as large as you want, since the level of detail is high.
The products will be delivered just the day after the end of the Kickstarter.
To show the level of detail expected, a sample gallery of the impressions made is shown below.
Here are the elastic goals for this campaign. Work will begin on these once the campaign has ended. Any new art will be presented here.
If these objectives are met, they will be updated and new ones will be added.
campaign.risks:

This project is for a set of STL files (digital files), so the risks are virtually nil. All files are modeled and have been printed with the Anycubic Photon 3D printer. The complete package is finished before the launch of Kickstarter so you can get your files as soon as the funds are released. The files will be immediately available once the kickstarter ends. Any problem that may arise with the models can be modified, updated and delivered to all sponsors.
